### **Self-Released** - DJ SWISHA – FIRST HAND SMOKE (Self-Released)
> Self-Released DJ SWISHA – FIRST HAND SMOKE On his debut album, New York club king DJ SWISHA samples house, R&B and pop, folding his encyclopedic music knowledge into a pointedly North American package. ### **Modern Love** - Carrier – Rhythm Immortal (Modern Love)
> Modern Love Carrier – Rhythm Immortal As a producer, Carrier specialises in white space. On Rhythm Immortal, the UK artist's use of percussion is the centrepiece, but the gaps he leaves in between the beats are the most compelling. Dub techno, ambient, industrial and jazz motifs unite in perfect harmony. Just listen to "Offshore," where slithering synths and hiccuping drums are tempered by saxophone and piano chords that gleam quietly like little spots of sun. ### **LATINCORE** - CRRDR – LATINCORE LEGEND (LATINCORE)
> LATINCORE CRRDR – LATINCORE LEGEND Bogotá's CRRDR doesn't take his title of "Latincore legend" lightly. The genre he champions takes the speeding BPMs and blistering intensity of hardstyle, blending it with guaracha, reggaeton and dembow. Throughout his debut album, bachata meets Jersey club ("Te Gusta Mi Bachata"), Eurodance fuses with guaracha ("Oh Baby") and IDM synths glimmer over a reggaeton beat. Tapping vocalists from Ecuador, Puerto Rico, Colombia, Mexico, Venezuela and Chile, this a sublime representation of the Latincore movement. ### Live At Dripping 
> Succubass Live At Dripping Seattle's Succubass is a pillar of the US DIY underground, and for their Friday night set at Dripping, they turned The Barn into a fever dream of bass and distortion. Moving from Zvvra's tactile techno and the dub of Gil.Barte to the heady steppers of Commodo & Gantz, Succubass stitches together something raw, cinematic and deeply physical. Each drop makes it feel like the music was testing the limits of the small room. ### MNMT 488 
> Andy Martin MNMT 488 Listen to any set from Kia, Priori or Cousin and you'll likely hear the dubbed out productions of Mexican-Jamaican producer Andy Martin. Based in Guadalajara, he has become a quiet force in the global underground, uniting sci-fi techno with the rhythmic sensibilities of the Caribbean and Latin America. For Norway's Monument Festival, he delivers a transportive set that moves from the weightless dub pressure of Bukkha and Abstract Man into sleek, hypnotic techno from Oscar Mulero and Unbalance. Here's an hour of music laced with deep bass, subtle psychedelia and shimmering percussive detail. ### IT.podcast.s14e07 
> Scott Zacharias IT.podcast.s14e07 Scott Zacharias has long been one of Detroit's best-kept secrets. His singular, offbeat taste has made his No Way Back sets the stuff of legend. This year's closing in the Outer Space Room was among his most personal yet—as Zacharias recounts in the description, his partner joined him on-stage at the end of the set to celebrate her pregnancy. ### **TAR / MM / UOH** - Titanic – HAGEN (TAR / MM / UOH)
> TAR / MM / UOH Titanic – HAGEN Titanic, the avant-garde project from producer and guitarist I. la Católica and cellist Mabe Fratti, returns with punkish elegance on HAGEN. ### Gavsborg - Kiosk Radio 
> Gavsborg Gavsborg - Kiosk Radio Jamaican dance music producers don't get the same recognition as their peers in Detroit, Chicago or Berlin. Hailing from East Kingston, Gavsborg carries the torch for this generation. The Berlin-based Equiknoxx founder has spent more than a decade reshaping dancehall with a leftfield sensibility—first breaking through with Busy Signal's charting single, "Step Out," before collaborating with everyone from reggae dub prince Addis Pablo to hip-hop icon Missy Elliott. On Brussels' Kiosk Radio, Gavsborg dropped a scorching mix of dancehall, jungle, zouk and dub, laced with the playful surrealism that defines his productions. ### GQOM MIX TAPES E67 | AUGUST 2025 w/ MAMTHUG 
> Mamthug GQOM MIX TAPES E67 | AUGUST 2025 w/ MAMTHUG "Archiving gqom, one mix at a time," reads the tagline for Oroko Radio resident Mamthug's GQOM MIX TAPES series. Emerging from Durban's townships in the early 2010s, gqom quickly became one of South Africa's most influential party genres, defined by heavy bass, stripped-back percussion and a brooding intensity. ### In Focus: DJ Medhi (mixed by Antonine Scali) 
> DJ Mehdi, Antoine Scali In Focus: DJ Medhi (mixed by Antonine Scali) NTS Radio's latest In Focus celebrates DJ Mehdi, a hip-hop-kid-turned-house-DJ who defined a generation of Paris nightlife in the early 2000s. Raised on the outskirts of the French capital by Tunisian parents, he began producing mixtapes and beats inspired by J Dilla, before emerging as an unlikely icon of the Paris party scene. His radiant selections helped stitch together disparate worlds, from Daft Punk and Justice to MC Solaar. This hour-long mix captures that alchemy: rugged, sample-heavy productions for 113, Rohff and Mafia K'1 Fry sit alongside glossy, synth-driven anthems like "Pocket Piano," culminating in the euphoric climax of Thomas Bangalter's edit of "Signatune." ### Truancy Volume 353 
> james K Truancy Volume 353 In the hands of james K, music becomes emotional architecture. Layering melancholy, surrender and longing alongside murkier feelings such as anxiety, the New York-based artist builds sets like an urban planner of the heart. This 74-minute trek across mediative downtempo, drum & bass and sample-based experimentalism finds through lines between artists on the opposite sides of the dance music spectrum, from the delicate piano notes of Tristan Arp to Marco Shuttle's quiet percussion. It ends on a bittersweet note with the IDM pop of Cybermission's "Deep Hard," which james K described as her "current favourite feeling" because "it's fun, beautiful and real." > Guadalajara-based favourite Andy Martin and the Parisian trio Sarcus Soundsystem take the reins of the dependably sick Dub Delights show on Rinse France. The result: two hours of dub-adjacent sounds, from Tikiman to Dubamine.

### The Bunker Podcast 233 (Mike Servito & Jeffrey Sifre)
> Of the many events across Movement weekend, Return to the Source makes for a consistent highlight. International Transmissions leads the event series encompassing parties like No Way Back and The Bunker, the latter of which hosted Mike Servito and Jeffrey Sfire earlier this year."Mike Servito always majestically closes out No Way Back, but what would this combination bring? Sfire brought the heat, and their styles melded in a slightly pitched-down form, music from all eras appeared," No Way Back cofounder BMG wrote of the duo's The Bunker mix on Instagram. "A magical closing set that naturally extended from two hours to five hours of pure heat from two DJs whose whole [lives are] this music and this culture—who could ask for more?"

## [September's Best Music](https://ra.co/features/4386)
Date: 2024-10-02T17:00:56.000Z

### Monolake - Studio (Imbalance Computer Music)
> The tenth Monolake album is Robert Henke's best in a decade. Most refreshing is that after a slew of academic-leaning releases, it sounds like he's finally having fun.Listen:Bandcamp

### Dar Disku - Dar Disku (Soundway Records)
> UK-based, Bahraini-born childhood friends Mazen AlMaskati and Vish Matre have long been on a journey to archive and safeguard the music that reminds them of home—with their own twist. On their self-titled debut album, they accomplish this so well that you'd be forgiven for thinking it was a reissue, not something released in 2024.Listen:Bandcamp

### Nídia & Valentina - Estradas (Latency)
> Two percussionists from vastly different sonic worlds meet up, and the results are astounding. Valentina Magaletti brings a warm human element to Nídia's sharp kuduro.Listen:Bandcamp

### Nala Sinephro - Endlessness (Warp)
> On Nala Sinephro's long-awaited second album, she transforms the glossy ambient-jazz that debuted on Space 1.8. This time, she hollows out the rich, meandering curvatures of jazz to land on isolated arpeggios that share more in common with ambient.Listen:Bandcamp

### Various - Dekmantel Ten: A Decade of Dekmantel Festival (Dekmantel)
> One of Europe's most respected festivals celebrates ten years with DJs inseparable from the event, with uneven results.Listen:Bandcamp

### Tim Reaper & Kloke - In Full Effect (Hyperdub)
> Hyperdub's first jungle album in 20 years lands with an expected bang. Two revered new-generation producers team up and unsurprisingly deliver.Listen:Bandcamp

### Floating Points - Cascade (Ninja Tune)
> After years of putting out jazz-electronica fusion, Floating Points returns to straight-forward, technicolour dance floor tracks.Listen:Bandcamp

### Sarah Davachi - The Head As Formm'd In The Crier's Choir (Late Music)
> One of the most ubiquitous Greek myths, Orpheus, is reimagined through Sarah Davachi's foreboding drone work, unlocking an even deeper emotional resonance in her compositions.Listen:Bandcamp

### LSDXOXO - DOGMA (Because Music)
> On his debut album, LSDXOXO, a producer who once banked on the success of his raunchy edits, makes his pop star transformation. Cleverly inverting early to mid-'00s pop motifs, he gives his sexy, unbridled production a clear running narrative.Listen:Bandcamp

### FKA twigs - Eusexua (Atlantic Records)
> The gorgeous lead single for the avant-pop star's new album mimics the sensation of a rising heartbeat: smooth, throbbing and desperate to breach the ribs and touch muscle to skin.Listen:Apple

### gyrofield - These Heavens (XL Recordings)
> Hong Kong producer gyrofield combines peculiar, miniscule parts to give their flawless drum & bass EP a distinct, off-world soundscape.Listen:Bandcamp

### Jiraffe - Out'A The Box (Still Music)
> A reissue of a propulsive, gritty 12-inch from Richie Weeks' Jiraffe alias serves as a mini time capsule of his ever-evolving artistic practice.Listen:Bandcamp

### Cosmo - JIN 09 (禁 JIN)
> Four tracks of aqueous house and techno that bottle the emotional expansiveness and cruising pace of Cosmo's DJ sets, full of understated acid tinges and sparkling melodies that land with impact despite their airiness.Listen:Bandcamp

### ani/live Fifty (CCL)
> Until this year, CCL had never played the mythical UK festival Freerotation—hard to believe, right? Luckily, the esteemed selector's 90-minute debut was recorded, joining Animalia's vaunted mix series."Playing one of the first sets and seeing the room, decor and the big bad subs of Room 2, years of fantastical lore and reality melded, I wanted to keep it sexy, wonky, trippy," they wrote. "Imagining a psychic electric swamp and how one would levitate through it... to the sky."

### Jaleo Real 2024 (Rachael)
> Originally from Zaragoza, Rachael is a favourite across Spain's underground scene. This stomping two-hour, all-vinyl set shows the Madrid-based DJ in excellent form. Recorded live at Jaleo Real, an intimate festival outside the capital, she moves through techno, breakbeat and hard house (including a killer rework of Brandy's "I Wanna Be Down") with pace and ease. One for any Eris Drew or Angel D'lite fan.

### Critical Sound Summer Sonics London (Samurai Breaks)
> The prolific UK producer and SUPER SONIC BOOTY BANGERS boss goes all in from the off in this live recording from The Cause, spinning 38 fast and freaky tunes in just over an hour. Proper Saturday night material.

### Sure Thing Mix 131 (Aaron J)
> With appearances at Draaimolen, Sustain-Release and Paral·lel, Aaron J is one of techno's best-kept secrets. This session from the 2024 edition of Above Below shows exactly why, balancing introspective records with abstract textures and subtle drive.

### Multisexual Mix 19 (Bennet)
> Berlin-based event series Multisex is an unabashed house music affair. Hannover-based DJ Bennet steps up for the latest edition of its mix series, perfectly capturing the party's steamy atmosphere, moving through everything from elegant dubbed-out cuts to floor-filling progressive material, all on vinyl.

### Sustain Release '23 (Ben UFO)
> No one does it quite like Ben. In this live set from Sustain-Release 2023, the Hessle Audio mastermind is in peak form, flowing effortlessly through the many shades of speed garage, wiggly tech house and wonky techno. His impeccable ear shines as he weaves together the summer anthems of 2023 and 2024—Theo Kottis’s "Lighthouse," Pangaea’s "Installation" and Peverlist's "Pulse VII"—making them feel both refreshingly new and warmly familiar.

### BFC Summer in the City 2024 @ Der Hintergarten (Ciel & Priori)
> This June, Ciel and Priori went back-to-back at the Breakfast Club in Amsterdam. The result: a near-three-hour recording that's equal parts deep, bumping and squelchy, moving through trance, tech house and bass-heavy techno with ease.

### The Lot Radio (Miscmeg)
> Melbourne mainstay Miscmeg steps up to New York's premier radio station, delivering an hour of romping minimal and blissful, bleepy tech house.

## [August's Best Music](https://ra.co/features/4373)
Date: 2024-09-04T15:00:02.000Z

### Seefeel - Everything Squared (Warp)
> The experimental band's first extended release in 13 years doesn't feel like a band trading on their reputation—the initial impression is one of change. Everything Squared finds Mark Clifford zeroing in on his production process while Sarah Peacock's vocals continue to provide a crucial human quality to the band's reliably enigmatic sound. Listen: Bandcamp

### Tinashe - Quantum Baby (Nice Life records)
> Outside the brief flirtations on Quantum Baby's singles—including of course, the viral hit "Nasty"—Tinashe's seventh album is really about striving for authenticity. The 22-minute album leans toward the hazy, subdued end of her catalogue, while still delivering on the kind of smoky, sexy numbers that we'd expect from her. Listen: Apple

### Kampire - Kampire Presents: A Dancefloor in Ndola (Strut)
> Kampire has helped champion envelope-pushing East and South African music from the '70s up to the present day. On her debut compilation, she steps into the role of curator proper. A Dancefloor in Ndola is a captivating exercise in crate-diggery, setting renowned heavyweights like Samba Mapangala and Tshala Muana next to unpolished gems with gritty production values, party-ready grooves and minimal Google footprints. Listen: Bandcamp

### Loidis - One Day (Incienso)
> Huerco S. brings back his Loidis alias on One Day, a stripped-back record that shows the producer falling back in love with the art of a simple loop. Across eight tracks, he writes deep, muted and wobbly rhythms filled with the sort of gorgeous dub techno melodicism you might hear on a Shinichi Atobe record. Listen: Bandcamp

### Chrystabell & David Lynch - Cellophane Memories (Sacred Bones)
> Across Cellophane Memories's 37 minutes, the pair's longstanding creative chemistry takes a new and arresting shape. Stripped of burdensome song forms and almost entirely absent of beats or easy melodies, something genuinely mysterious emerges—a mystery you'd be tempted to describe as "Lynchian" even without knowing who was behind it. Listen: Bandcamp

### Jon Hopkins - Ritual (Domino)
> Jon Hopkins began his journey making "serious, emotional" music with 2021's hazy, beatless Music For Psychedelic Therapy. The follow-up to that album, Ritual, originated from music Hopkins wrote for an installation called Dreamachine, named after a 1959 invention heralded as "the first art object to be seen with eyes closed." The 41-minute composition expands into eight parts that unfurl like a guided meditation. Listen: Apple

### Laurie Anderson - Amelia (Nonesuch)
> When Laurie Anderson—who first conceived of Amelia as a stage performance 24 years ago—was asked on BBC Radio 4 why Amelia Earhart's story appealed to her, the answer was simple: "She was a bad-girl pilot—and I liked that." On the LP, Anderson follows the late pilot's final flight path. The album plays like an audio documentary, drawing directly from Earhart's writing and strapping us into the plane with Earhart with shaky, surround-sound instrumentation. Listen: Bandcamp

### Various - Time Passages 10 Years (Time Passages)
> A decade is a long time in dance music, but longevity looks good on the techno label Time Passages. On the anniversary compilation, Binh's label remains the high watermark for low-slung and sinister minimal electro and techno. Listen: SoundCloud

### Nectax - Body Talk (Play:Musik)
> On the first release in 14 years on Play:Musik, Nectax brings the same shapeshifting energy of the label's early output. Across four slickly produced tracks, he connects elements of footwork, jungle, techno and hardcore on an impressively varied EP that vividly reimagines the sonic kinship between those genres. Listen: Bandcamp

### Danny Daze & Jonny From Space - Tumbadora EP (Craigie Knowles)
> On Tumbadora, Danny Daze and Jonny From Space reunite for an EP that swaps the introspection of their respective debut albums for three original cuts of sludgy, polyrhythmic electro and techno. It even includes a cameo from Miami's other wunderkind, Nick León. Listen: Bandcamp

### Ciel & CCL - Tilda's Goat Stare (NAFF)
> On Tilda's Goat Stare, Ciel & CCL's debut collaboration's chaotic feminist streak found a fitting anchor in the 2002 sci-fi feminist film Teknolust. Much of the EP lands with a thwack, top-loaded with precisely the kind of dusty peak-time tracks you'd find in the duo's festival sets. Listen: Bandcamp

### Dubbel Dutch - Cosmic Tone Poems (Rare Earth Tones)
> Over a decade since Dubbel Dutch's last solo release, one of the breakthrough stars of the post-dubstep bubble returns after literally going off the grid. Cosmic Tone Poems is built around the contrast between synth lines that float like champagne bubbles and basslines that plunge the tracks down to earth, updating the sort of genre promiscuity he championed in the '10s. Listen: Bandcamp

### gyrofield - These Heavens (XL Recordings)
> The producer makes their debut on XL with a dynamic EP inspired by a night out in Bristol. Over four tracks, they swerve from angular acidlines to delectable, sputtering drum & bass breaks. Listen: Bandcamp

### All Arthur Russell DJ set, live at The Barbican (JD Twitch)
> Optimo's JD Twitch dives into Arthur Russell's vast catalogue for this live recording at London's Barbican Centre back in May, celebrating the late composer's extraordinary life.

### GROOVE Podcast 428 (Mattias El Mansouri)
> For the 428th GROOVE Podcast, Stockholm-based DJ and producer Mattias El Mansouri delivers a stellar two-hour mix, traversing eclectic boogies from the likes of The Durutti Column and Barrington Levy to the deep minimal rhythms of Arkajo and Dorisburg.

### XLR8R Podcast 863 (Assyouti)
> The Berlin-based producer and DJ goes tear-out, spinning hard-as-nails choppage from the likes of Breakage, B-Key and Champa B. If you like your drum & bass dark and weighty, this one's for you.

### Rinse FM (Ploy)
> While he may have initially made his name releasing wonky bassbin tracks on the likes of Hessle Audio, Timedance and Hemlock, Ploy isn't one to be pinned down. On the July edition of his Rinse FM show, the Bristol-based DJ and producer demonstrates that he's equally comfortable (and excellent) at playing house.

### Freerotation 2024 : The House Of Crocodiles Part 2 (Live Recording) (Nono Gigsta)
> No rhythm, tempo or genre is off limits in this truly ecstatic and goosebump-inducing set, recorded live at Freerotation from Cashmere Radio resident Nono Gigsta. Oh and there's not one but two Björk moments—enjoy.

### Kiosk Radio 11.08.2024 (DJ Maria)
> With regular appearances at Berghain, Bassiani and VENT, DJ MARIA. is one of the best DJs to emerge out of Japan in recent years.Guesting on Kiosk Radio, the Tokyo-based artist delivers a masterclass in building atmosphere, perfectly balancing muscle with texture (including one particularly mind-bending transition in which it sounds like she mixes a field recording from a working kitchen into Ben Klock's "Wolf"). It's the kind of eye-opening session that makes you want to listen to all her other mixes right after.

### Live at Nowadays 7 April 2024 (Objekt)
> Objekt is one of the most dynamic artists in underground techno today, and this recording—from the equally influential New York club Nowadays—captures him on typically excellent form."I played on Sunday morning from 9 AM to 3 PM, between JASSS and Bearcat," he said, calling it "one of the most creatively fulfilling sets I can remember playing–one of those sets where the audience, environment, atmosphere, tech setup, phase of the moon, whatever, all somehow lined up for a full six hours."

### Down The Rabbit Hole 2024 (Sarkawt Hamad)
> The versatile Amsterdam-based DJ covers a lot of ground in this two-hour live recording from Down The Rabbit Hole. You can hear her adventurous approach in full bloom, moving through starry-eyed house, hypnotic techno, squelchy acid and more from the likes of Peach, Polygonia and Zephyr.

## [The Best Releases of 2025](https://ra.co/features/4350)
Date: 2025-12-02T11:00:25.000Z

### Emotional Machine Funk2025 has been defined by the collapse of techno optimism. Where the nascent internet's frontier spirit once pointed to a bright future, today that promise feels sinister, curdled 
> Emotional Machine Funk2025 has been defined by the collapse of techno optimism. Where the nascent internet's frontier spirit once pointed to a bright future, today that promise feels sinister, curdled by the "corporate gloom" and data extraction documented in Liz Pelly's excellent book, Mood Machine. The year's most compelling machine funk reflects this irradiated state of distress on a personal and collective level, as well as caution about what our technological destiny truly holds.The electro, techno and slanted IDM we listened to in 2025 went beyond techno pessimism to focus on other knotty concepts, such as grief and loss, provoking visceral gut punches to attain those physical highs. It's music that makes you feel and move, which, if you go back to Detroit techno's history, has always been there. No one told this story better than the Motor City's early pioneers, whose fragile and furious proto-techno output was never blindly optimistic. RA's staff picks of the year pull from this DNA: DJ Bone's The End Of Never, with its muscular electro, stands as the embodiment of Detroit, rooted in a '90s urban reality that focused on interrogating systems of power and decay.These ghosts of past motifs echo through these releases, which are neither hopeful nor nostalgic throwbacks. This is machine music deeply rooted in the turmoil of the present, asserting that the sound of the zeitgeist refuses to be background noise. It's a defiant new link in a chain of creation that speaks to adversity, and it demands that we listen. What does that say about 2025, that artists are trying to produce music that says something through bleeps and bloops again?– Chloe LulaRecord of the YearBlawanSickElixirAfter more than a decade at the forefront of club music, Blawan could easily have settled into legacy act territory, churning out formulaic imitations of past successes from the comfort of the techno assembly line. Instead, on SickElixir, he doubles down on innovation.The album finds the UK artist at his most vulnerable. Themes of grief, trauma and addiction (he recently spoke to Crack about having to leave Berlin after drugs "basically shattered" his life there) are folded into serrated rhythms and monstrous, almost bodily vocal work—even fleeting moments of warmth arrive refracted through a darker lens. The ferocity of his early work remains, yet the melodic smears, fragmented vocal gasps and unexpectedly tender swells reflect an artist intent on expanding his emotional bandwidth. SickElixir sees Blawan turn years of experience into something raw and profound.– Michael LawsonRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsMarie DavidsonCity Of ClownsIn a world shackled by surveillance capitalism, Marie Davidson posits what might be the only true subversion left: satirising this power structure with sexual hedonism run rampant. City Of Clowns brings this madcap concept to life. Thunderous, funky basslines and mind-melting electro synths are helmed by Davidson, who plays the Alexa-like narrator gone rogue, extolling the virtues of data mining with expletives and double entendres. If the machinist future our tech overlords are envisioning is even one tenth as sexy as this, bring on the singularity.– Jake IndianaRead the full reviewListen:BandcampUnspecified EnemiesRomance in the Age of Adaptive FeedbackPart of the enduring magic of '90s Detroit-school techno is how the producers made pieces of hardware sing. Louis Digital isn't from Detroit and it isn't the mid-90s, but you can't tell by listening to Romance in the Age of Adaptive Feedback. Equal parts nostalgic and futuristic, brimming with feeling and assembly-line grooves, the record is a pitch-perfect homage to classic Motor City techno and electro by a true lover of the form.– Henry IvryRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksDJ Bone"Deep Inside"On "Deep Inside," DJ Bone pairs his famously surgical drumwork with a simple vocal mantra, a reminder that there's a human pulse driving the circuitry. As the oscillating synths kick in, elastic and almost overcooked, the track feels like a machine learning its purpose, pushed by a human hand that refuses to let the gears lock into place. The way he flares open the mix turns his tight grid into something that emulates a living, breathing organism.– Reid BGRead the full reviewListen:BandcampSandwell District"Hidden"Austere techno brutalism be damned—on End Beginnings highlight, "Hidden," Regis and Function returned to their Sandwell District project with a rounded melodic sound that found its pocket and leaned deep into it. The track's interplay between insistent acid, throbbing mono synth bass and syncopated sub rumble displays a funkiness more readily associated with Motor City titans. "Hidden" evokes the shadowy, emotive pulse of Carl Craig classic "Sandstorms" while giving it the Sandwell District pressure-cooker treatment.– Oli WarwickRead the full reviewListen:BandcampMixLimited NetworkITPS119 LIMITED NETWORKAs Limited Network, Detroit-based artist Max Watts channels the city's lineage, using the TB-303 to connect classic machine funk with its sleek 2020s mutation. His Ilian Tape mix opens with tight 303 sequences: clean resonance peaks, controlled envelopes and a filter sweep that traces a line from forebears like Robert Hood and Jeff Mills. Rather than treat acid as nostalgia, the mix unfolds with curiosity, moving through Drexciya-esque passages and punchy electro workouts. Watts honours Detroit's foundations while showing how the machine-funk blueprint still resonates today.– Bella AquilinaListen:SoundCloudFurther ListeningPolygonia, Wata IgarashiCross PassageListen:BandcampBlack SitesR4Listen:BandcampEhua"Aria"Listen:BandcampBarker"Stochastic Drift"Read the reviewListen:BandcampTraxxThe Definitive Articles of House Music Chapter 6Listen:SoundCloudListen to the Emotional Machine Funk playlistSpotify

### Bass WeightWe should've clocked it when FWD>> and Tempa returned. From late 2024 through 2025, bass weight has been pushed into new places. From Bristol outlet Dimeshift, which continues to lead fresh 
> Bass WeightWe should've clocked it when FWD>> and Tempa returned. From late 2024 through 2025, bass weight has been pushed into new places. From Bristol outlet Dimeshift, which continues to lead fresh, first wave-inspired dubstep, to Beatrice M., who released a strong run of their own tunes, as well as issuing music from the likes of Tighe, Old Man Crane and Dangermami via their label, Bait.Across the board, artists increasingly unified the roots of sound system music with their own astute, modern twists, propelled by a more femme-led, internationally reaching school of artists and labels. Introspekt's Moving the Center unlocked a newfound sensuality in dubstep and dark garage; tracks like Mia Koden's "Skank Steady" bottled anticipation for summer with floating keys and a warm bassline; Lauren Duffus's excellent Can's Gone Warm EP served weighty alt-pop, folding in trip-hop and post-dubstep shimmer reminiscent of Kelela's Cut 4 Me. And then Tracey & Riko Dan's "Sex Life" abandoned elegance entirely, taking a thrumming low-end and plonking a pithy hook on top: "All I wanna do is fuck, fuck, fuck, fuck, fuck."Alongside Beatrice M., names like EMA were busy earning much-deserved flowers with standout festival sets, while legends assembled in the form of Mala and dub techno veteran Paul St. Hilaire, who collaborated on "Like It's Always Been," the opening track on St. Hilaire's album. In a year that Timedance and SPE:C turned ten (and Tectonic hit 20), techno-infused bass weight stocks are arguably at an all-time high, and sound system music at large is, in all senses of the word, booming.– Nathan EvansRecord of the YearPaul St. Hilairew/ the ProducersFor Kynant Records' Richard Akingbehin and the voice of dub techno, Paul St. Hilaire, the decision to summon the ghost of Rhythm & Sound's seminal 2003 album, w/ the Artists, was classy yet bold. Would w/ the Producers build on its source material? Or risk living in its shadow? The album's faultless cast of collaborators, including Batu, Shinichi Atobe and Azu Tiwaline, made failure impossible. As a sonic aesthetic, dubwise is flourishing right now, and this LP bottles its power and beauty in myriad tones and tempos, from Mala's orchestral skank on "Like It's Always Been" to the slo-mo psych thump of Aurora Halal & DJ G's "Mary Jane Greenfield." The pièce de résistance is, of course, St. Hilaire himself. He graces every beat with poise and purpose, never overdoing it. As the years roll by, once-mythic musicians can lose touch with their former brilliance. Not this Dominican dub poet.– Carlos HawthornRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsIntrospektMoving The CenterIntrospekt has what you want and what you need. Sound familiar? You might recognise those words from KMA Productions' '96 garage track "Cape Fear," which Introspekt samples on "Subliminate," the final track on her debut album. From the New York-based artist, what we want is something new, fresh and stimulating in a way we've not experienced before. And what we need is dubstep. Introspekt delivers both, making bass-heavy 140 riddims sound smoother and sexier than ever.– Sam DaviesRead the full reviewListen:Bandcampex_libris001 & 002Every time Dave Huismans returns, it's cause for celebration. Just one catch: the lexicon of writers and fans alike falls short in capturing his aversion to fixed form. What exactly is ex_libris? Iridescent, deep electronics, backed by a swirl of percussion and an exceptional attention to textural detail? Rolls right off the tongue. At any rate, this headphone-friendly double drop sums the qualities of his best-known projects—2562's swampy low-end, A Made Up Sound's nonlinear jams—in a teeming soundscape with an almost hydraulic sense of progression. "It has a lot of character," he once told us about his gear, "and that's why I like it." Dave, the feeling's mutual.– Gabriel SzatanListen:BandcampTracksTracey"Sex Life"The anonymous London-based duo knocked everyone out of the park with their self-titled debut. Press play once and you'll be convinced. "Sex Life" is deadly dubstep in classic form, with a searing verse from vaunted MC Riko Dan. But then, there's a twist. "Sex Life" also features surprising interludes of twinkling synths and bubblegum vocal loops with a bedroom pop feel—inflections that add a touch of irreverent internet humour. It's a perfect marriage of neon pop and bass weight—a uniquely 2025 take on dubstep.– Nyshka ChandranListen:BandcampLauren Duffus"N.U.M.T.E."Lauren Duffus's Can's Gone Warm EP is her best work yet. The track inhabits the liminal space between the club and the lonely hours after closing, leaving a lingering sense of longing wrapped in mystery. It's exactly the kind of idiosyncratic, emotionally vivid production that marked Duffus as one of the year's most compelling artists.– Fahad AkinsanyaListen:BandcampMixBeatrice M.THE DUBSTEP - TECH HOUSE CONNECTIONIn this NTS Radio entry, Beatrice M. explores the connection between two once maligned genres, dubstep and tech house. ### Paul St. Hilairew/ the ProducersFor Kynant Records' Richard Akingbehin and the voice of dub techno, Paul St. Hilaire, the decision to summon the ghost of Rhythm & Sound's seminal 2003 album, w/ the Ar 
> Paul St. Hilairew/ the ProducersFor Kynant Records' Richard Akingbehin and the voice of dub techno, Paul St. Hilaire, the decision to summon the ghost of Rhythm & Sound's seminal 2003 album, w/ the Artists, was classy yet bold. Would w/ the Producers build on its source material? Or risk living in its shadow? The album's faultless cast of collaborators, including Batu, Shinichi Atobe and Azu Tiwaline, made failure impossible. As a sonic aesthetic, dubwise is flourishing right now, and this LP bottles its power and beauty in myriad tones and tempos, from Mala's orchestral skank on "Like It's Always Been" to the slo-mo psych thump of Aurora Halal & DJ G's "Mary Jane Greenfield." The pièce de résistance is, of course, St. Hilaire himself. He graces every beat with poise and purpose, never overdoing it. As the years roll by, once-mythic musicians can lose touch with their former brilliance. Not this Dominican dub poet.– Carlos HawthornRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

### Neo Electronic PopFrom Ray of Light to BRAT, pop records have long repurposed club culture to delight the masses. But in 2025, a sort of reverse osmosis emerged: cutting-edge producers found new avenu 
> Neo Electronic PopFrom Ray of Light to BRAT, pop records have long repurposed club culture to delight the masses. But in 2025, a sort of reverse osmosis emerged: cutting-edge producers found new avenues for experimentation in pop's effervescent packaging. From Shanti Celeste's glossy love songs on Romance to Oli XL's K-pop meets IDM on Lick The Lens, there's a clear uptick in the use of radio-ready melodies. In a moment when big-room dance music is more mainstream (and more mind-numbing) than ever, underground artists returned to pop as a point of subversion; a new way to enliven drum & bass, trance and trip-hop without sullying the source material.The relationship between pop and dance music dates back to the '80s, when artists like Boy George and The Human League first conceived of pop as a self-aware art form, not a chart metric. Their vision was fuelled by the same anti-establishment spirit that influenced club innovators like Larry Heard and Underground Resistance. In 2025, pop sounds more in line with that original art punk mentality than it has in decades. There's always been pop worth dancing to, but it's been a long time since so many skilled dance music producers have contributed to the cause.– Hattie LindertRecord of the YearOklouchoke enoughThe off‑centre vaporwave pop songs on Oklou's radical debut make for perfect bedroom music. The French musician's hypnagogic dream logic and tender harmonies render life's most existential moments with microscopic precision and a lulling calm. "endless" opens like a beacon from a far‑off village, her dulcet, auto‑tuned vocals shutting out all notifications from the outside world. "thank you for recording" turns surveillance into a lullaby, while "blade bird" crystallises the album's themes of attachment and harm into weightless nursery rhymes. In the background hum of 2025's global crises, this kind of dissociative dream pop feels spot on, turning panic into an exquisitely arranged experience. This is a record for soft clubbing; for dreamers who want the night to blur rather than explode.– Gio SantiagoRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordskeiyaAhooke's lawIt's rare to be transported inside an artist's head. keiyaA's second album is so expressive that listeners can almost hear her neurons crackling as she crafts track after track of achingly intimate music. It's like reading her diary, while also pilfering her drug stash. The Chicago-raised artist translates the chaos of heartbreak, self-doubt, rage and mental illness into a brilliant bricolage of experimental pop and R&B. These 19 cuts are surreal and unsettling, but also raw and truthful, portraying soul music as both escapism and catharsis.– Cameron CookRead the full reviewListen:BandcampPinkPantheressFancy ThatPinkPantheress crashed into 2025 with a mixtape that supercharged the London producer's breakbeat-driven sound. Her recognisable traits—a core palette of UKG, jungle, drum & bass; Y2K-era samples, conversational vocals—remain, but overall, Fancy That is so bold and bright that it feels like a reinvention. Hands-in-the-air moments, faster tempos and peak-time melodies are abundant. With surprise summer hits like the Underworld-sampling "Illegal" and the Groove Armada-inspired "Stateside," the young luminary proved she can go from being an internet star to the leader of club-pop's next generation.– Shaad D'SouzaRead the full reviewListen:SpotifyTracksFKA twigs"Girl Feels Good"Eusexua is all about revelation—the sensation of finding your true self "under a hard metal silver stiletto on the damp rave floor." On "Girl Feels Good," the album's trip-hop highlight, the UK multi-hyphenate celebrates this sentiment with unbridled joy. Over brooding guitar and an entrancing techno-pop chorus, she sings how a woman's blossoming pleasure can fill a night with infinite potential. A proper ode to female desire, this is a song as sacred as it is profane.– Vrinda JagotaRead the full reviewListen:SpotifyRochelle Jordan"Bite The Bait"Rochelle Jordan's sixth album, Through The Wall, served a masterclass in assured and sexy house with a pop sheen. "Bite The Bait," produced by regular collaborator Jimmy Edgar, is a late-night R&B jam where the Chicago artist's teasing, honeyed soprano drips over stripped-back drums."Pulled up to the party it was me, myself and I / Breaking hella hearts I didn't even have to try," she sings, radiating a quiet confidence that carries the track right from the club to the afters at dawn.– Katie ThomasListen:BandcampMixbambinodjLIVE FROM EARTH Mix 79If you've fallen for the hazy alt-pop of Oklou or Malibu, you'll find a kindred spirit in bambinodj. His music welds the Black diasporic sounds of shatta, amapiano and Flex Dance Music with trance, ambient and IDM. These aren't genres that a DJ would typically pair, but in bambinodj's world, it makes perfect sense. This mix encapsulates his sonic DNA: downtempo Balearic haze, inscrutable SoundCloud oddities, Caribbean rhythms and majestic piano leads that put Marc Cohn's Walking in Memphis to shame.– Fahad AkinsanyaListen:SoundCloudFurther ListeningSudan ArchivesThe BPMListen:BandcampJim Legxacyblack british music (2025)Listen:BandcampFcukers"Play Me"Listen:BandcampGeorge Riley"Private Life"Listen:SpotifyMalibuUnited In Flames w/ JAMESJAMESJAMESListen:SoundCloudListen to the Neo Electronic Pop playlistSpotify

### Noise DistortionDance music's edges have frayed in fascinating ways in 2025. Whether an attempt to make sense of a world still vibrating with instability, or simply a rejection of the overpolished clu 
> Noise DistortionDance music's edges have frayed in fascinating ways in 2025. Whether an attempt to make sense of a world still vibrating with instability, or simply a rejection of the overpolished club tools that continue to flood the scene, some of the year's best releases have been forged from the cracks—records that find beauty in disintegration.At the centre of this shift is a renewed fascination with noise and distortion, not only as sonic aesthetic but as emotional language. Disparate artists seem to be drawn to sounds that carry strain, abrasion or a sense of dislocation. Distortion communicates pressure—be that in a personal sense or wider communities navigating upheaval. Even when artists such as Los Thuthanaka or aya pushed their palettes into raw or blown-out territory, it was less about harshness for its own sake and more about revealing what lay beneath the polish.Equally, distortion took on a more introspective bent. Producers working in slower or more reflective modes—Klein, DJ Haram, Rainy Miller—leaned into erosion as a kind of emotional texture. Their use of noise suggested memory slipping, feelings blurring, structures softening rather than breaking.While far from a new phenomenon, perhaps this turn toward noise is a response to an era defined by overstimulation. Amid algorithmic smoothness and endless playlists, distortion feels like something human again. It restores the club's physicality: a reminder that dance music has always thrived on what doesn't quite fit, on frequencies that shake your body as much as they move your feet.– Michael LawsonRecord of the YearLos ThuthanakaLos ThuthanakaUnless you experience synesthesia, listening to Los Thuthanaka might be the closest you'll get to seeing sound. Digitised Andean folk music brings to mind brown mountains and deep blue lakes, while corroded synths are redlined to evoke a radioactive lime green. The first collaborative album from siblings Joshua Crampton and Chuquimamani-Condori melds Andean folk, queer psychedelia and staticky ambient into an ultra-digital experience. Crampton's chugging electric guitar provides the bedrock, setting the atmosphere ablaze while Chuquimamani-Condori gets busy with their sampler, adding bursts of humour via cartoonish, pitched-down voices yelling "Yo!" or "Grrrrr!" over sun-dappled rhythms. These crackling loops become heaving, transcendental waves of sound, haptic feedback sent all the way down from their ancestors.– Kiana MicklesRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsayahexed!Trauma scuffs your spirit, the way an explosion leaves your ears ringing. aya's mesmerising second album seeks to confront her past battles with substance addiction head-on and out loud. The album is rife with one detonation after another, conveying the dark side of the never-ending afters. Muddy digital roar becomes purifying fire; the feedback of a siren's call pulls you in like a friend begging you to party. But listen through to the end of the record, and you'll hear the victorious sound of newfound self-control.– Jesse DorrisRead the full reviewListen:BandcampDJ KRadio Libertadora !On his debut LP, PANICO NO SUBMUNDO, São Paulo producer DJ K made as much noise as possible, defying conservative efforts to silence Brazilian funk with walls of tuin-tinged sub-bass unique to bruxaria, his preferred strain. His second album, Radio Libertadora !, focuses more on favela life and its anarchy. He raps about the daughter of a doctor who chooses to be a marginal (thug) on "SOBREVIVE CONTRA O ESTADO," his words ringing loud and clear above the fanfare. For DJ K, noise is freedom.– Joseph FrancisRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksDJ Haram"Fishnets feat. Bbymutha, SHA RAY & August Fanon""Fishnets," the third single on DJ Haram's debut album Beside Myself, plays with opacity. Over buckling 808s, a warped Arabic violin conveys that dissolution itself might be an exercise in control. DJ Haram and August Fanon's enigmatic boom bap is a thrilling vehicle for Bbymutha and SHA RAY's cocky-yet-gleeful verses. "Fishnets" is a testament to the survival of the spirit as an artist grappling with a global hellscape. Squaring up to the stale systems in power has never sounded more infectious.– Isabel LingRead the full reviewListen:BandcampKlein"blood on the flag""blood on the flag" closes out Klein's bludgeoning guitar record, thirteen sense, with a mixture of desperation and righteous fury. Norwegian black metal levels of serrated fuzz bleed into midrange frequencies, while boisterous drums cut the wall of hiss before everything vanishes in a rush of glissando. It feels as if the previous 37 minutes sublimate into air: the track's final howl reduced to a breeze blowing through wind chimes, a fragile calm earned through terrifying catharsis. In other words: this, too, shall pass.– Andrew RyceRead the full reviewListen:BandcampMixmi-elIn Dreams for The Trilogy TapesA gloomy XXYYXX classic sits beside an Alan Watts speech, a horny Outkast track is saddled next to heavy breathing. mi-el's In Dreams is viscerally unnerving. But peak freak arrives an hour in, as she judders from aya's ketamine-induced paranoia to the experimental rap of Conway The Machine like it's the most natural transition in the world. Darkly mesmerising, the mix feels like a personalised hand-me-down from a sibling, meant to keep you up at night while shaping your taste.– Tom GledhillListen:SoundCloudFurther ListeningJane RemoverRevengeseekerzRead the reviewListen:BandcampDJ TravellaTwende - Dance ClassicsListen:BandcampDebit"La Ronda y el sonidero"Read the reviewListen:SoundCloudSkrillex"ANDY"Read the reviewListen:SpotifysoftburnObjet Personnel w/ softburnListen:SoundCloudListen to the Noise Distortion playlistSpotify

### Guitar JamsRight now, guitars are everywhere in electronic music, a reflection of the great blending of genres that's defined the past five years. In 2025, albums were rarely anchored to one sound, of 
> Guitar JamsRight now, guitars are everywhere in electronic music, a reflection of the great blending of genres that's defined the past five years. In 2025, albums were rarely anchored to one sound, often enlisting the malleable quality of the guitar to transform electronic beats into rock ballads. As one of the oldest instruments, guitars can provoke a jolt of time-worn emotion. That tug on the heart when you hear a lonely minor key? Practically baked into human DNA. Ambling post-rock arpeggios can inspire visions of pastoral terrain, while an indie-pop glissando might give you a new lease of life. Fans clamour to see Smerz's dramatic live rendition of "You got time and I got money," while at home they hit replay for the moping chords that stretch out below the duo's honeyed lyrics.Rock faded out of the mainstream in the late '00s, as EDM, rap and pop surged across the next decade. The genre struggled to reclaim its place in the zeitgeist, until a post-pandemic malaise stalked the music industry and everyone reached for their guitars. Copenhagen—which, in addition to Smerz, is home to Astrid Sonne, ML Buch and Erika de Casier—led the charge. Using the guitar as a textural tool, these artists built layers atop introspective electronic foundations. They bottled a year of political turmoil and economic decline into songs that felt double-sided, capturing a youthful angst alongside a yearning for something, anything, more.– Kiana MicklesRecord of the Yearjames KFriendOn Friend, Jamie Krasner wields her guitar with the freedom of an acrobat flying through the air. Using space to transformative effect, she defies expectations of electronic pop songwriting through her mastery of genre. Wispy tones lap gently against glowing reverbed vocals, bringing an expansive feel to the album's unique strain of ethereality.There's no doubt Krasner can shred in a more classic indie rock vein (see "On God"'s swathes of dream pop chords), but where she really excels is in transforming the guitar altogether through sampling and meticulously applied FX. Whether it's chugging alongside the peppy heartbeat drums on "Play," sputtering over choral vocal samples on the cavernous "Rider" or undulating at the core of trip-hoppy "Blinkmoth (July Mix)," her guitar shapeshifts throughout Friend's electronic landscape as mutably as a synth could.– Sue ParkRead the full reviewListen:BandcampRecordsAcopiaBlush ResponseAcopia's third album is a shimmering haze of shoegaze guitars and soft, yearning vocals. Moving away from the drum programming and grittier, bass-driven sound of previous records, Blush Response revels in downtempo, sparse grooves and cool-headed trip-hop. Vocalist Kate Durman channels her lilting soubrette over distorted fuzz, reverb-laden guitar tones and the wonky harmonics of tracks like "Chase Me" and "Let Down." The album is a dreamlike, wafting soundworld seen through bleary eyes.– Ammar KaliaRead the full reviewListen:BandcampJoanne RobertsonBlurrrIn a year full of albums that sound like they might have drifted from an abandoned campsite, Blurrr distinguishes itself with the subtle spectrum of sound it teases from everyday tools. The UK musician's guitar groans in her hands as much as it sings, always a low, solid counterweight to her floating and translucent voice. This is an album that envelopes you like mist: slowly, imperceptibly, until all of a sudden it's all you can see.– Sasha GeffenRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksSmerz"You got time and I got money"On "You got time and I've got money," Smerz cement their claim to Scandi fame. It's the Copenhagen duo's own "Bittersweet Symphony," an orchestral love song that documents the thrill of a new relationship. Although the track's smoky bass guitar plucks a refrain in D minor sharp—the key of mourning—it still lands as a serene dispatch from the honeymoon phase, all warm embraces and waking up together. Over the smoothest drumline of the year, Catharina Stoltenberg and Henriette Motzfeldt wallow in a grounded romance: patient, consistent and built to endure.– Hattie LindertListen:BandcampNourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic second album, The Passionate Ones, establishes a remarkable sweep. The Baltimore singer teases out love's inherent freneticism, while the arrangements shift wildly—a frantic dynamic for frantic times. Eventually, the protean musical sensibility whips the urgent central lyric, "If I'm gonna go insane / At least I'm loved by you," into a mantra for the steadfast and enamoured. The effect is irresistible.– Daniel FelsenthalRead the full reviewListen:BandcampMixLogic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things downtempo across a vapour trail of ambient dub, of-the-moment trip-hop and esoteric Scandi pop. Leaning into picks from some of 2025's most talked-about artists—james K, Smerz, Purelink, Oklou, Blood Orange and Yves Tumor—the Australian producer and DJ turned in a guitar-laced tincture of self-care, swapping house bangers for home-listening gems.– April Clare WelshRead the full reviewListen:BandcampFurther ListeningModel / ActrizPirouetteRead the reviewListen:BandcampBlood OrangeEssex HoneyRead the reviewListen:SpotifySaffron Bloom"Flame Never Dies"Listen:BandcampRaisa K"Stay feat. ### Nourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic sec 
> Nourished By Time"Max Potential"The brazen heart of "Max Potential" is riven: between passion and resignation, romance and staying true to oneself. This standout from Nourished By Time's fantastic second album, The Passionate Ones, establishes a remarkable sweep. The Baltimore singer teases out love's inherent freneticism, while the arrangements shift wildly—a frantic dynamic for frantic times. Eventually, the protean musical sensibility whips the urgent central lyric, "If I'm gonna go insane / At least I'm loved by you," into a mantra for the steadfast and enamoured. The effect is irresistible.– Daniel FelsenthalRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

### Logic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things do 
> Logic1000DJ​-​Kicks: Logic1000Conceived as a "little piece of serenity," Logic1000's dreamy, zoned-out mix for !K7's iconic DJ-Kicks series wrapped us in a cocoon, capturing the mood for all things downtempo across a vapour trail of ambient dub, of-the-moment trip-hop and esoteric Scandi pop. Leaning into picks from some of 2025's most talked-about artists—james K, Smerz, Purelink, Oklou, Blood Orange and Yves Tumor—the Australian producer and DJ turned in a guitar-laced tincture of self-care, swapping house bangers for home-listening gems.– April Clare WelshRead the full reviewListen:Bandcamp

### Club HeatersAt the end of every year, we usually identify a single track that seemed to unite every club and festival stage. Think Maya Jane Coles' "What They Say," Kassem Mosse's "Untitled (A1)" or J 
> Club HeatersAt the end of every year, we usually identify a single track that seemed to unite every club and festival stage. Think Maya Jane Coles' "What They Say," Kassem Mosse's "Untitled (A1)" or Joy Orbison's 2024 smash "flight fm," tracks that sliced clean through our imagined trenches and could make any dance floor move in unison.In 2025, it felt like that moment never quite materialised. Don't get us wrong: the absence of a unanimous dance floor heater doesn't mean there wasn't a slew of excellent club music coming out. It's more that the heat got more localised. It's long been true that what goes off in, say, New York, stands apart from what works in Ibiza, and this year, those differences made the notion of a single, standout club anthem untenable.The lack of universal hits, however, meant more breathing room. This year, the producers soundtracking peak-time moments have stayed small, specific and rooted. For the cohort revelling against AI slop, algorithmic sameness and other homogenising forces, the result was a landscape defined by artistic pluralism and local autonomy rather than one-size-fits-all trends.This shift hints at progress. The appetite for hard and fast persists, sure, but it mutated, shaped by space, crowd and context. Instead of one monolithic sound dominating the scene, you get micro-moments: whether that be the Come Round EP by DJ PGZ & Yikes, two Aboriginal producers staking their claim on the sound of Australian dance floors and bush doofs; or Kiara Scuro and Sugar Free, whose respective releases channelled a sleazy, slow-burning chug familiar to anyone who has clocked in hours at fabric or Houghton. A welcome reminder that the notion of peak time can—and should—offer something different for every floor.– Bella AquilinaRecord of the YearDJ PGZ & YikesCome RoundCome Round has the unbridled energy of a peak-time dance floor coursing through it. Gunai/Kurnai and Yorta Yorta artist DJ PGZ and Boorloo-based Wongi artist Yikes forged their bond in underground spaces—from DJ PGZ attending formative queer parties to inviting Yikes to play his first set at Sub Club in Naarm. Here, that early spark comes full circle. Across solo cuts, cross-remixes and a standout joint track, "Ouss Ouss," the release maps two artists searching for, and ultimately locking into, unity in their respective sounds.It's full throttle from the get‑go: all big, wubby basslines, fierce vocal chops and swirling crescendos that summon the kind of feral inhibition only a grimy basement can unlock. DJ PGZ's pulsing hard techno interlocks with Yikes's spacious, trance-leaning grooves, all threaded by percussive broken beats. The result captures a powerful moment, as two First Nations producers propel Australian dance music into its next chapter.– Hannah DoodyListen:BandcampRecordsKiara ScuroNight Crush​​On Kassian's Rinse FM show in February, Rosie Ama described Night Crush, the debut (and final) Kiara Scuro EP, as "an ode to being on the dance floor when you don't really know what time it is." That disoriented thrill runs through all three tracks: the haziness of heavy reverb and the way the deep, rolling grooves lock your body into the rhythm. Every so often, a repeating riff on opener "Witching Hour" invites that movement, murmuring "body, in motion." File this one with your favourite Planet Euphorique releases.– Katie ThomasListen:BandcampSugar FreeDisociandoJust like her DJ sets, Sugar Free's debut EP squirms with amoebic movement. Disociando's prog house and tech house cuts swell and contract like jellyfish in water, balancing moments of hips-swaying bliss with heads-down enthralment. Pared-back drums add tension and a touch of sleaze, while gorgeous textural details—oddball synth burbles and feedback buildups—bring a zany experimentalism into the mix. This striking amalgam of psychedelia, minimal house and bounce is a peak-time treat with grit and groove, but it's also slinky enough to work the afters.– Nyshka ChandranRead the full reviewListen:BandcampTracksWOST"Banda"Not "banda" as in band, but as in crew. This Spanish translation nails the mantra of the global posse that WOST and Colombian label TraTraTrax have been rallying over the years. On "Banda," the Bogotá-based producer unleashes a percussive cut that's travelled from Video Club to Rinse FM. There's FM synthesis, a drum breakdown and a sped-up dembow tresillo beat so syncopated it sounds like it might mutate into dubstep with each bar. As the gap between the Latin American and UK undergrounds keeps closing, "Banda" proves electronic fusion never has to dilute flavour.– Rachel Grace AlmeidaListen:BandcampJump Source"On (feat. Martyn Bootyspoon)"Patrick Holland and Priori have been quietly producing with other artists—like james K and Physical Therapy—from their Montreal studio. They've still had time to crank out earworms like "On," a euphoric club track so infectious it disarms even the most dedicated techno purists. The confluence of Jump Source's meticulous production and Martyn Bootyspoon's signature vocal swagger is a showcase in style that feels both retro-futurist and viscerally current. In a sense, it's the sound of 2025—a reach for nostalgic sounds that sits undeniably in the present.– Chloe LulaListen:BandcampMixDJ Tobzy Imole GiwaLagos City UnloadedThe algorithm demands bitesized clips of DJs blending belters together. You can either curse this tyranny, or do like DJ Tobzy Imole Giwa does and exaggerate the formula. On Lagos City Unloaded, the cruise beat DJ blitzes through hyperspeed pop, R&B and Eurodance alongside continental genres like Afrobeat, kwaito and amapiano. During one flurry, Lil Wayne's famous "A Milli" a capella creeps in with the subtlety of Looney Tunes's Sylvester before being ousted by the Tweety Bird-pitched trill of Yves Larock's "Rise Up." As DJ Tobzy pushes everything he touches to cartoonish extremes, he makes disparate genres find copious common ground.– Joseph FrancisListen:BandcampFurther ListeningBaaltiMelaRead the reviewListen:BandcampPloyIt's Later Than You ThinkRead the reviewListen:BandcampKhadija Al Hanafi"Bounce It On The Flo"Listen:BandcampJSPORT"No Turning Back"Listen:BandcampKontronatura b2b Nick LeónCarnaval Novo AffairListen:SoundCloudListen to the Club Heaters playlistSpotify
