All in all, the mix delivers an uppercut of infectious optimism in a new chapter defined by post-pandemic growing pains. —Whitney Wei

### fabric presents (Leon Vynehall)
> Creative pressure is a very real thing for artists. How does one constantly evolve and meet—even surpass—their best work? Leon Vynehall seems to know the answer. Since 2018's powerful conceptual album Nothing Is Still, the UK musician has matured from a talented club producer into a storyteller par excellence, weaving original and compelling narratives through sound. 2019's RA-recommended DJ-Kicks was one of the best mixes that year. Now, in 2022, he's charted again. Like DJ-Kicks, fabric presents Leon Vynehall is all about dynamics, except this time the focus is on the club. You'd think that might be restrictive, but Vynehall is a master at finding common threads and energies in disparate musical worlds. Here, work by Mala, A2, Or:la, Ehua, Lady Blacktronika, Commodo, Hagan, Skee Mask and textures from so many other producers hang together in a smoky, soulful soup. The stitching is sublime, the music consistently excellent. At points, it's enough to take your breath away. —Carlos Hawthorn

### Live At Dimensions 2021 (Joe Delon)
> Hot take: Joe Delon likes dance music more than just about anyone. He tours all the time, but still finds time to write a regular newsletter about everything going on around him. As a DJ he exudes enthusiasm, playing groovy records that run the gamut from sleek contemporary tech house to old school Italo classics. This live recording from Dimensions captures his range perfectly: he starts low and slow, but just as things get a bit heady, he makes a U-turn with the outrageous vocal track "Adventure" by Eleanor and Shep Pettibone. From there, things dart between the cerebral and the cheesy. Vintage hip house gives way to G-funk-laced electro and acid before dissipating into celestial techno and old school rave. It's hard to imagine that even the security team wasn't losing it during this masterclass in Tisno. —Henry Ivy

### Accidental Meetings Podcast #72 (Yumi)
> New York DJ Yumi was probably a new name to a lot of people when they first heard this mix for UK platform Accidental Meetings, but anyone who did listen was probably left hungry for more. This 66-minute journey is the kind of unassuming but carefully built mix that lays eggs in your brain and hatches weeks later. Eventually, before you know it, you'll memorize every transition. Speaking of transitions, they're all remarkably seamless as Yumi blends together odd tracks at various tempos, gradually pulling off a 30 BPM change so impeccably that you barely notice it. Maybe RA staffer livwutang put it best in one of the SoundCloud comments: "dude [this] is fucking wild… im glad im alive to hear this sound." —Andrew Ryce

### HÖR, January 13 2022 (D Dan)
> Berlin-based DJ and Mala Junta resident D.Dan had a big year. Seemingly unknown during the recesses of the pandemic, he catapulted to international acclaim in the last 18 months, not only because of his unanticipated glut of speed-demon dance floor releases—all of which skirt the 150 BPM mark—but also because of his position at the helm of a refreshing new trend towards nimble, groovy techno. His HÖR Berlin mix from January this year perfectly encapsulates this style. Minimal yet replete with understated hooks, it layers psychedelic flurries of toms with tribal drums, house vocals and trancey melodic fills. Strategically moving from rhythmic tracks to deep peak-time riffs and back, he showcases here why he's become such a lauded underground tastemaker—and a name to watch. —Chloe Lula

### Juanita's 063 (Quest?onmarq)
> "Spiraling" is a concept central to quest?onmarq's work. The New York-based DJ hosts a Lot Radio show of the same name, which sees them exploring a vast range of genres, from breaks to gqom, experimental and the harder regions of techno. They are not only technically skilled, but they have also been gifted with an insatiable curiosity about music, which allows them to play pretty much anything. For the 420-themed mix series, Juanita's—a platform on which DJs typically showcase the slower, sweet-tempered end of their collections—quest?onmarq turned to hazy breaks. The windswept mix breezes past early works like Equinox's rattling "Taking Over" to contemporary jungle like "For The Headstrong" by Tim Reaper & Response. It's a tutorial in considered pacing, showcasing how to play fast while maintaining a subdued energy. —Kiana Mickles

### Untitled 909 117 (Toumba)
> Dubby, dark and loaded with gnarly bassweight, Toumba's Untitled 909 Podcast is a beastly mix that infuses halftime mutations with a sense of industrial-tinged dread. It's a perfect introduction to the Amman-based artist, whose style nods to Nervous Horizon, Hessle Audio (home to his latest EP) and Nyege Nyege Tapes. The up-and-coming producer shows off his love for tectonic basslines, footwork, hiphop, Middle East folk rhythms and hybrid club music from the developing world during this 80-minute session, which features South Korea's NET GALA gqom ensemble Phelimuncasi reworked into a glitchy bricolage, as well as Dua Saleh's delicate trap. Toumba plays for the dance floor, but he's not afraid to indulge in experimental atmospherics and distorted textures either. This sense of adventure makes this mix powerful—and a whole lot of fun. —Nyshka Chandran

### Honcho Podcast Series 108 (Kilopatrah Jones)
> On September 15th, Haitian-born, Queens-based DJ Kilopatrah Jones wrote on Instagram: "When you think of house music, what do you think of? For me, it's house dancing, getting free on the beat with a friend [you] made on the dance floor." The 108th edition of the Honcho Podcast Series, delivered by Jones as a special Pride mix, encapsulates this feeling—the joy of dancing, moving your body in sync with the kindred spirit on the dance floor you met just moments ago. Full of piano riffs, sensual vocals and a whole lot of groove, Kilopatrah Jones's Honcho offering is an hour of brilliant, ecstatic house that will make you dance until you sweat. —Katie Thomas

### BSU 066 (Truly Madly)
> It's possible that Michael Joyce, AKA Truly Madly, is jumping between two or three different tracks in the first six minutes of his Butter Side Up Mix. It's also entirely possible that Joyce owns a 12-inch that somehow overlays sweeping chords with gurning rave stabs, rolling hand drums and short-circuiting electrical currents. The fact that we'll likely never know the answer is part of the fun (plus, it's not like we'd be able to find any of the records he plays anyways). This two-hour treasure trove of all things '90s sees Joyce in particularly bouncy and jubilant form. There are Latin-flavored rhythms, vintage NY vocals, and little bits of proper late night garage. The mixing is seamless without being showy, and Joyce keeps us on the edge of our seats the whole time, wondering what Shazam-breaking gem he'll reach for next. —H.I.

### Live From Sugar Hill (Jon K)
> Striking twists and turns are what make Live From Sugar Hill such a sharp and dynamic mix worthy of the physical media it was released on. Taken from Jon Kraus's set for Club Night Club at Brooklyn’s Sugar Hill Disco in September 2021, the cassette (released this year) niftily winds through bouts of grime, baile funk, gqom, ballroom and Jersey club like an alpine skier through a mogul field. Moments of more atmospheric, experimental tunes tease respite here and there, but Kraus knows the attention span of a dance floor all too well. On Live From Sugar Hill, a volley of breaks or a wall of kick drums is always only just around the corner. —Joseph Francis

## [The Best Tracks of 2022](https://ra.co/features/4098)
Date: 2022-12-20T15:45:42.000Z

### Nick León feat. DJ Babatr - Xtasis (TraTraTrax)
> If 2022 belongs to anyone, it's Nick León. The Miami producer is at the forefront of a new wave of 305-area artists who fuse together the city's unique tapestry of Hispanic cultures—and its deep connections to Latin America—with its robust dance music history. León specifically mixes influences from reggaeton and perreo into what is sometimes termed "Latin tribal techno," but whatever you want to call it, there's no denying the appeal of "Xtasis," the track most of us heard out on dance floors more than any other, by a country mile. "Xtasis," a collaboration with Venezuelan raptor house pioneer DJ Babatr, is a good example of the intercontinental cross-pollination happening within this scene. The percussion plays a trick, both four-on-the-floor and broken at the same time, at a chemically-enhanced pace with distant vocal wails that add a lysergic flair. But "Xtasis"—and its accompanying Pearson Sound and Doctor Jeep remixes—really clicks with the old-school organ bassline that drops in at about the two-minute mark. It's something so simple, so familiar and, frankly, genius, that by the time the kick drum drops back in, the room should be in a frenzy. If it isn't, then you're probably in the wrong place. —Andrew Ryce Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Kelela - Washed Away (Warp Records)
> It's a special, and rare, moment when music drops and completely disrupts the flow of the internet. This was the case with Kelela's "Washed Away," her first single since she put out her acclaimed debut album Take Me Apart five years ago. During the hiatus, she looked inward and studied literature on misogynoir, Black labour and racial capitalism. Suffused in hazy pads and reverbed vocals that sound more like mantras than vocal refrains, "Washed Away" could be perceived as the release of all this collective pain. In a recent interview with Dazed, Kelela described the single as a "heart check-in," a song recorded to "send out a clear message to Black people, who are my core audience and who I intend this music for, that you n***as are worthy." Message received. — Kiana Mickles Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Rhyw - Honey Badger (Voam)
> On paper, "Honey Badger" shouldn't work. Its main drum line moves in and out of time with the impatience of a toddler hammering at a sequencer. The sole synth—the closest the track has to a melody—is aggressively abrasive, as if it were made from a substance somewhere between quicksand and sandpaper. But I'll be damned if it isn't one of the catchiest tracks I've heard all year. Undeniably weird, but equally infectious, if you heard the track out (and odds are you did if you went to a festival this summer), it sent every crowd into full blown meltdown. Walking away from any set where it was deployed meant that there were punters with their heads still spinning trying to shriek along to those metallic snares. —Henry Ivry Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### A+A - Eternal September (AD 93)
> Both times I heard "Eternal September" this summer I didn't know what it was. On each occasion, it was sunrise at a festival, those blissful hours when time seems to stand still as the sky changes from milky to glowing. It's an ideal track for those hazy moments, with swathes of lush organ chords and fluttering high notes that swoop around like birds with silk wings. When Avalon Emerson and Anunaku (AKA TSVI) shared the upcoming release online, Midland commented on the former's Instagram saying: "I have played these songs and had a nice time while doing so!" To which I thought: I have danced to these songs and had a nice time while doing so! —Katie Thomas Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### DJ Plead - Come Quick (Livity Sound)
> DJ Plead usually plays and produces slick, percussive zingers that meld traditional rhythms from the Middle East with high-tempo dance music. But on his second offering for Livity Sound, the Nervous Horizon core member switches out his frenzied pace for a more pared-down tone. Drums remain his core ingredient but the mood is more whimsical, making the record feel more like a score to a picnic in the park rather than a party. Despite its light-hearted nature, "Come Quick" is still loaded with sharp corners and jolting melodies—a true day to dusk record. —Nyshka Chandran Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Ahadadream - Spaceship (More Time)
> Imagine Lunice, DJ Lag, Roska and Benga linking up for a recording session, and you start to get a sense of what "Spaceship" sounds like. On an EP filled with massive, celebratory tracks, Ahadadream's "Spaceship" was colossal. Every few bars it felt like he was shifting his reference points. What starts as a UK-funky-meets-gqom hybrid morphs into a dubstep throwback with its airy, descending melody. But then the xylophone chimes and upbeat snares capture the maximalism of TNGHT records. As the inadequacy of comparison should make clear, though, "Spaceship" is sui generis, announcing the arrival of a new torchbearer for all things big and bassy. —H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Pariah - Caterpillar (Voam)
> It's been a few years since Pariah put out any solo material (he's primarily active as one half of Karenn alongside Blawan). It's been even longer since he released dance music in his own right. Caterpillar, then—which came out in June on Voam, the label he runs with Blawan—is an exciting interruption to this interlude. The hypnotic title track is capital-T techno, but it's heavily textured and nuanced, layering dense modular noodlings with a repeating guttural squelch that sounds more like an off-the-cuff live rip than the polished veneer of most of today's peak-time output. Flanged-out percussion, sizzling analog stabs and a spacey, Pole Group-like synth lead make it the ultimate selection for breaking open a late night set. —Chloe Lula Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### DJ Python - Angel (Incienso)
> At first listen, it's almost unbelievable that Brian Piñyero, better known by his pseudonyms DJ Python and Luis, creates his ambient reggaeton in Ridgewood, Queens. "Angel," off of his EP Club Sentimientos, Vol. 2, has a lot of heart and an even gooier center in its sonic embrace of supple electronics. The ten minute-plus track feels like a weekend-long sojourn into a daydream far from the Halsey L stop, as lush—almost levitating—synth pads breathe deeply around pattering tablas and soufflé riddims. Within its sumptuous depths, there's an earnest, refreshingly unironic appeal to softening, unfolding and tenderness. —Whitney Wei Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Sally C - Downtown (Big Saldo's Chunkers)
> When Sally C released the second EP on her label Big Saldo's Chunkers back in April, the tracks had already been doing the rounds for almost a year. Most notable was "Downtown," a big, brash, in-your-face hip house roller that encapsulates what Sally C and her pals mean when they refer to a "chunker." This is functional, no-nonsense dance music that does exactly what it needs to: make your body want to move and groove. The vocal samples are textbook—"Put the needle on the record" and "Do you want to dance?"—but they're a consummate companion for a tune designed to keep the party pumping, proof that less isn't always more. —K.T. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Nikki Nair - Step 2 (n goes to infinity)
> It's hard to imagine following dance music in 2022 and not hearing at least a handful of Nikki Nair tracks. The genre-hopping polyglot was everywhere with everyone, establishing a tight but all-over-the-place sound that blends electro, drum & bass, jungle and footwork. Case in point, "Step 2," which kicked off Nair's own label n goes to infinity. It starts out as hectic uptempo acid jungle track, before crescendoing into a halftime breakdown full of metallic skronks and other aural detritus. It's like walking from a FABRICLIVE night into a Daedalus set circa 2011, and then finishes off with a sprightly techno-jungle jig that feels completely of the moment—an era that Nair is helping define with each new release. —A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### GiGi FM - Manas (PST) (Bambe)
> GiGi FM's first signed EP, Magnetite, supposedly holds "spiritually-charged techno mantras." While that may conjure a suite of vaguely spiritual motifs, we get none of that on this kinetic four-tracker. "Manas (PST)" embodies her aesthetic most distinctly, nodding subtly to the artist's sometimes collaborator, Donato Dozzy, with its deeply tribal percussive intro. The rest of the song is beguilingly simple; the propulsive kick-and-tom pattern continues uninterrupted under a single-note cowbell, never changing except for a brief drop about two-thirds in. GiGi FM, an alumnus of both the New York City Ballet and the Alvin Ailey Theatre, has said that the release is a testament to the ritualistic relationship between movement and music. This synergistic dynamic is elegantly elicited on the EP's A2, which is trance-inducingly danceable. —C.L. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Heavee - Sonic Warfare (Hyperdub)
> Heavee's Audio Assault was probably our favourite record on Hyperdub this year, with six tracks of inventive hybrid footwork that capture the label's ethos to a T. The best example was probably "Sonic Warfare"—which shares its name with Kode9's book—a blend of jabby footwork drums, eerie synths and a melodic motif that stutters and fades like electrical interference. —A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Physical Therapy - Emotional Rescue (Allergy Season)
> Physical Therapy spent the last four years working diligently behind the scenes on his label, Allergy Season, as well as releasing records via a slew of his other aliases (Car Culture, DJ Overnite and Fatherhood, his project with Michael Magnan, to name a few). His last release under his original moniker, the 2015 EP Million Years Crushed, was deep, busy and granular. His latest album, Teardrops On My Garage, sounds like a subdued version of Physical Therapy. The garage-inspired chopped vocals are pitched-up and sweet, the melodies resonant and rich. My personal favourite, "Emotional Rescue," is an edit of Tru Faith's "Let The Beat Hit 'Em," that brightens the source material's original vocals with a sparkling melody and rollicking breaks. —K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Isabella Lovestory - Exibisionista (Self-released)
> Reggaeton has been undergoing a renaissance in the electronic music world in recent years as artists like Rosa Pistola and the trio Sangra Nueva dissect dembow loops with a toolbox of global club rhythms, producing a kaleidoscope of sub-genres. Among those fringe styles is perreopop, and Isabella Lovestory is one of its leading faces. Here, her sultry lyrics and cam girl aesthetic take on an almost spooky air thanks to producers Nick León and Kamixlo who inject elements of dub and industrial into classic dancehall patterns. Transforming what would have been a regular pop song into a deadly dance floor weapon, the trio are a bright example of reggaeton's futuristic sector. —N.C. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Eliza Rose & Interplanetary Criminal - B.O.T.A. (Rosebud Recordings)
> If, when one of SASS played "B.O.T.A." at around 8 AM on the Sunday morning of Love International, someone had said to me: "This tune's going to be #1 in the UK," I probably would have laughed and suggested it was time for bed. "B.O.T.A." was the summer's most ubiquitous tune, yes, but in my universe of clubs and festivals. Or so I thought. Skip to Friday, September 2nd, 2022, and Eliza Rose & Interplanetary Criminal had scored the UK's 1,400th #1, the first-ever for a woman British DJ. The percussion is simple and buoyant, the chords are warm and the vocal is catchy as fuck; "B.O.T.A." is a flawless summer bop. —K.T. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Nia Archives - Forbidden Feelingz (HIJINXX)
> British jungle revivalist Nia Archives began her astronomical year releasing a slew of hits du jour and ended it by winning a MOBO award in the ceremony's very first electronic/dance music category. "Forbidden Feelingz," an accelerated Amen break-laden single off her eponymous EP, combines elements of dub and reggae with a distinctly rough-and-ready, old-school UK feel. Nia Archives enthusiastically borrows vintage sensibilities, so the spectre of sound system culture still haunts this one, but to a timeless and earwormy effect. —W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Maara - Lezzies In A Jacuzzi (Radiant Love)
> Montréal-based Maara has cultivated a fun and femme queer aesthetic that found an appropriate home on the Berlin label Radiant Love. Her EP on the imprint, Goddess Within, features four Goa-leaning trance tunes accompanied by whimsical titles like "Mommy's In Trouble" and "Goddess Within (Give It To Me Daddy)." But it's "Lezzies In A Jacuzzi" that takes the cake for name and substance alike. This anthem layers heavily gated vocals over a throbbing kick and swooning, euphoric pads. Thoughtfully-placed flourishes—a breakbeat fill, a call-and-response arpeggiated synth—elevate this song from cheesy crowd-pleaser to considered dance music production. If the Canadian artist is pointing her ship towards prog, then we're jumping on board. —C.L. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

### Margaret Dygas - Butterfly Effect (Half Baked Records)
> The best minimal tracks are all about attention to detail, so it should come as no surprise that Margaret Dygas' "Butterfly Effect" clocks in at 9:09. The track is immersed in the micro world of details as she dilates and contracts looped conga drums, 909s, a creeping synthline and stormy pressure from her subs. Simple but effective, Dygas approaches these elements with a surgeon's precision as she moves them up and down in the mix. This was Dygas's first 12-inch in over half a decade, a welcome return of one of minimal's weirdos-in-chief. "Butterfly Effect" is a reminder of the strange sense of wonder that only the best minimal can create, where it feels like a loop could go on forever. —H.I. Listen: Soundcloud

### Utada Hikaru - Somewhere Near Marseilles (Epic Records)
> The year's greatest grown-and-sexy jam came out of an unlikely collaboration between the biggest J-pop star of all time and UK house producer Floating Points. Starting with the flicker of an acid line, "Somewhere Near Marseilles" unfolds over 11 minutes of exquisitely produced house, bobbing and glimmering in all the right places. Hikaru sings what feels like three different choruses in a mixture of English and Japanese, glamourously exhorting their lover to meet them in Marseilles as an in-between point between London and Paris. "Let's go fast, then go slow," they repeat over the constantly morphing instrumental track. It's a snippet of luxury and contentment that feels as lush as the song sounds, only improved by Hikaru's impeccable vocal performance—the way she sings, "I'm in London / You're in Paris" is both commanding and effortlessly cool. It's rare that the pleasures of pop and house music come together this well, a cosmopolitan adult contemporary jam made for the most amourous hours of the night. —A.R. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify

### Kush Jones - BX Bounce (Self-released)
> Growing up in New York, it's nearly impossible not to be inundated by different strains of music. The summer streets come alive with reggae and hip-hop; house music wafts in through FM radio or from the cracked window of your longtime neighbour. The vital life force and diversity of the city's sounds has coloured Kush Jones's discography over the years. He typically releases music—drawing from house, jungle, footwork and hip-hop—independently at a fast clip. One of his many works from this year was 6 Days, an EP that was written in, you guessed it, six days. Within a record that shifts rapidly between house and juke, the highlight comes from the pensive pads, idle, honey-sweet melody and subtle percussion on opener "BX Bounce," embodying the very best of New York's intangible cultural heritage. —K.M. Listen: Bandcamp

### Beyoncé - BREAK MY SOUL (Columbia Records)
> When Beyoncé released the first single from her album Renaissance, souls weren't the only thing she broke. The internet, arbiter of half-baked opinions, waxed enthusiastic about house music's reinvigoration within the commercial mainstream. In many ways, "Break My Soul" was formulaic in its hitmaking: it flung gruff yak'ing samples of New Orleans bounce legend Big Freedia ("release ya trade / release the stress / release the love / forget the rest") into a looping bassline inspired by Robin S.'s 1990 smash "Show Me Love"—even tapping into the post-pandemic cultural zeitgeist of saying "fuck it" and quitting your job. But the key to any liberation anthem is confidence, not necessarily originality, and Beyoncé stands on the shoulders of the tried-and-true house heroes that came long before her to successfully ignite the masses. —W.W. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Peggy Gou - I Go (Soulwax Remix) (Gudu Records)
> In the remix circuit, Soulwax hold a god-tier status. Known for transforming pop, indie and rock classics into expansive dance music epics, the Belgian duo don't take themselves too seriously, tending to zero in on hands-in-the-air euphoria. Their reworking of Peggy Gou's "I Go," is fun-loving to the core, but it's also a potent warehouse banger. Teasing out the original's delicate vocals and retro synths against a fierce, almost mechanical bassline, the remix balances both light and heavy textures with a masterful touch. The breakdowns are on-point, the quirky bird call sample is delightful and there are no boring moments. Soulwax strikes again. —N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Shanti Celeste - Cutie (Hessle Audio)
> As an illustrator, Shanti Celeste has a predilection for bright, happy hues—a blush pink to be precise, if we use her latest EP artwork as a reference. Her Hessle Audio debut adds a welcome splash of colour for the label in the form of two tracks and a Central remix that fizz with winsome positivity. Opener "Cutie" is the standout, idiosyncratically Shanti in its nimble drums and gossamer pads, with a pitched-up, corkscrew of a vocal she recorded herself. It skips along at 140 BPM, settling in the playful sweet spot where heads-down, driving house meets radiant and beatific textures. —K.T. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Skin On Skin - Burn Dem Bridges (FFRR)
> It seems unbelievable that it took someone this long to combine UK drill and techno as perfectly as this. It only took an Australian to do it. In a year that saw his star rise almost absurdly rapidly—and deservedly so—Skin On Skin blew us away with "Burn Dem Bridges," which samples a Sav'o and Horrid1 track and saddles it onto an urgent techno beat with an addictive descending bassline. The whole thing sounds ready to blow at any minute. It's remarkable how a rhythm can change the cadence of a vocal so much, and in Skin On Skin's hands, both drill and techno sound completely fresh, fiery and unstoppable. —A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Two Shell - home (Mainframe Audio)
> Impersonators showed up to their Boiler Room to play a pre-recorded set. Their first interview was taken off the internet in mere hours. Two Shell blew down the doors of 2022. And while some of their gimmicks may split opinions, "home" was a unifying track beloved by the dance music community. The single marked a new direction for the London duo, setting them apart from their peers by creating a completely singular sound where bubblegum pop meets UK bass. A frothing breakbeat at 160 BPM drives the track under its SOPHIE-reminiscent vocal, meanwhile its neon melodies burst like fireworks across the stereo spectrum. "home" will be remembered the way "Hyph Mango" was, marking the entrance into some unknown, but exciting era of UK club music. —H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### KH - Looking At Your Pager (Self-released)
> In many ways, 2022 was a massive year for pop music. Underground club producers have long played out cheeky edits of '90s chart-toppers in their DJ sets, but it felt more prominent this year. Under his KH alias, Four Tet brilliantly reworks 3LW's "No More (Baby I'ma Do Right)," autotuning the original lispy vocals against a mean bass synth and a cooing, sparkling melody that feels straight out of a nursery rhyme. It's teen pop in holy matrimony with garage-like beats, plus a faint hint of dubstep—a combination that only someone like Four Tet could pull off. —N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### SHE Spells Doom - Bossano (All-centre)
> "Trying to see how African rhythms combine with techno for me is an experiment," said Wamya Tembo AKA SHE Spells Doom in an interview with the Zambian press. "[I like] seeing how far you can push it while still making people want to dance." His latest Afrobeat techno tune, "Bossano," toys with tension with the poise of a tightrope walker. Bursts of percussion ruffle the song’s militant batida march, punctuating every bar of sci-fi synths while also teasing the ruckus of a street party throughout. Like an ellipsis, it brings you to the edge of your seat—or rather, the tips of your toes. —Joseph Francis Listen: Bandcamp

### Paurro - Galavisión (Cómeme)
> This lean breakbeat house number serves as a definitive introduction to Paurro's dynamic sound. Combining UK garage and dub influences with psychedelic effects, "Galavisión" is the kind of immersive groove that lends itself to escapist fantasies. Whether hearing it at home or at the club, it's easy to be transported into a lush dream state, one where pleasure and instinct hold more currency than logic. Paurro understands the power of skippy rhythms and low-end frequencies, letting them shine without indulging in too many choppy breaks. With its clear '90s influences and rollicking drums, "Galavisión" is perfect for both peak time and after hours. —N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Jennifer Loveless - Around The World (Butter Sessions)
> Galloping, loopy house abounds on this Melbourne producer's EP for home-turf label Butter Sessions. "Around The World" encapsulates the experiences of being a contemporary jetset flâneur, whose lackadaisical saunters are replaced with fast-paced globetrotting. This all seems immediately interpreted through glitchy, disembodied vocals—like filtered announcements over an intercom—and roving, rotund basslines that seem to spend the entire seven-plus minutes attempting to catch up with themselves. Loveless's perspectives bounce—quite literally—in palpable optimism. There's an dazzling array of life out there to see, and simply not enough time to see it all. —W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Joy Orbison - Pinky Ring (Hinge Finger)
> No year-end list is complete without a Joy Orbison banger. If the South Londoner's talent is distilling pockets of the hardcore continuum into original bitesize chunks, "Pinky Ring" is a particularly golden nugget. Breaks, drum & bass, post-dubstep, possibly even electro? It's all in there, and yet the track feels anything but retro. Making the past sound fresh and futuristic could well be Joy Orbison's greatest skill. —Carlos Hawthorn Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

## [The Best Albums of 2022](https://ra.co/features/4077)
Date: 2022-12-15T09:30:58.000Z

### D. Tiffany & Roza Terenzi - Edge Of Innocence (Delicate Records)
> Electronic music is something of an ouroboros: sounds hark back to the past as trends recycle in a never-ending loop. The revival of genres like jungle and trance, among others, is proof positive, and the subject of many articles from cultural critics like Simon Reynolds and Mark Fisher. But there's a distinction to be made here. Some artists' chase of rose-tinted nostalgia is nothing more than empty cliché, while others treat their return to a bygone era like a hero's journey—familiar, yet eclipsed by a new, fortified sensibility. D. Tiffany and Roza Terenzi achieve the ideal balance on their debut album, Edge Of Innocence. It offers a mélange of influences that run the hi-BPM gamut from electro to drum & bass without losing grip of the rippling, psychedelic groove at the core of everything this duo do. "Grains Of Sand" is a case in point, replete with synths that stab through a thicket of lumbering percussion, as is the fittingly named breakbeat bop "Redemption Arc," kitted out with all the sleek dynamism that emerges after a period of dark contemplation. By the end of Edge Of Innocence, you get the feeling that, though the duo are working with well-worn sounds, they've made them all their own. -Whitney Wei Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Hudson Mohawke - Cry Sugar (Warp Records)
> Ross Birchard told us he only works up the nerve to make a solo album about every seven years, and this time it was worth the wait. Like a summary of his history of making weirdo IDM hip-hop and mainstream rap, Cry Sugar is the Glaswegian producer's most epic and wide-ranging LP, chock full of earwormy melodies, left-turn smackdowns and the symphonic pomp-and-circumstance that makes his work one of a kind. You can hear the last ten years of rap music refracted through Birchard's many-sided prism, which is often as funny as it is heavy as it is genius. Like the title implies, Cry Sugar careens from the depressed to the euphoric, each feeling pumped up to the scale of a Marvel movie. -Andrew Ryce Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Black Rave Culture - Black Rave Culture Vol. 2 (Black Rave Culture Records)
> One of the most potent club weapons this year, the second offering from Washington DC supergroup Black Rave Culture is a motley crew of historical dance music styles from across the Black diaspora. Representing East Coast club, junglist rhythms and sunny house music with a truly holistic, cross-genre vision, the album teems with grit, unbridled energy and most importantly, power. From the baile funk underpinning "Never Left" to the '90s rave ethos of "Peace Plan," these tracks jump across styles effortlessly, and the fine-tuned production of members Amal, DJ Nativesun and James Bangura holds it all together. -Nyshka Chandran Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Kerri Chandler - Spaces And Places (Kaoz Theory)
> When it comes to making music, too many house and techno legends struggle to hold a candle to their younger selves. Not Kerri Chandler. The US house giant's latest album, Spaces And Places, is a three-hour epic stacked with the kind of tasty grooves and lush instrumentation we've all been gobbling up for 30 years. That its 24 tracks were mostly recorded inside the clubs and venues they pay homage to is both a remarkable feat and a quirky novelty. But it also speaks to something more profound: Chandler's global, enduring popularity. -Carlos Hawthorn Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Shygirl - Nymph (Because Music)
> As someone who's been listening to Shygirl since her breakthrough single, "Want More," it might have come as a surprise that the UK artist only released her debut album this year. But as the saying goes, good things take time. This record, aptly titled Nymph—a play on words nodding to the album's whimsical nature and bawdy undertones—is Shygirl in full effect. The vocalist's hooks are tighter than ever, and the ever-expansive production spans pastoral pop, raunchy hip-hop, nostalgic Eurodance and the kind of saccharine hyperpop that trends on TikTok. More than just an excellent first LP, Nymph is a masterclass on collaboration, boasting production credits like Sega Bodega, Arca, Mura Masa and more, whose work melts effortlessly into Shygirl's one-of-a-kind style. -Kiana Mickles Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Carmen Villain - Only Love From Now On (Smalltown Supersound)
> Norwegian musician Carmen Villain has a preternatural ability to evoke a sense of cold, uneasy beauty. Her fourth album, Only Love From Now On, features ambient compositions that are often startling in their psychological intrigue. On "Future Memory," Villain expertly braids the sounds of cooing birds, humming flutes and irregular heartbeats to build suspense. "Liminal Space" conjures something similar, except with the inclusion of what seems like faint, irregular footsteps that stumble closer and further away. With its disarming atmospherics, Villain's fourth full-length has nothing to declare—only quiet intensities to whisper. -W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Waajeed - Memoirs Of Hi-Tech Jazz (Tresor)
> Waajeed's debut on the prestigious Tresor label is a tribute to his hometown of Detroit, as a rousing tribute to both Black leisure and resistance against oppression. Conceptualised with a mini road trip around the Motor City—specifically, from the his own Underground Music Academy to Belle Isle—Memoirs Of Hi-Tech Jazz connects the dots between Detroit's rich musical traditions, encompassing jazz, deep house, minimal techno and marching band music. Even the title, a reference to the Underground Resistance subgroup Galaxy 2 Galaxy, reflects Detroit's storied sonic lineage. Proud, joyous and unapologetically local, Waajeed's love letter to his hometown is packed with velvety tones and lustrous chords that acknowledge the past and pave the way for the future. -N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Marina Herlop - Pripyat (PAN)
> Do you ever wonder how the world looks through a baby's eyes? Everything's new, and nothing makes sense. It's just one brilliant, ever-shifting mirage of colour and sound. Marina Herlop's third album, Pripyat, dazzles in a similar way. Where the Catalan artist's first two records showed off her expert piano playing and freeform, wordless vocals, Pripyat goes a step further into the unknown, patching together her classical training with dissonant electronics, and even weaving in an ancient Indian singing style called konnakol. The album might share its name with a ghost town, but Herlop's Pripyat is alive and bright with boundless imagination. -Joseph Francis Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Whatever The Weather - Whatever The Weather (Ghostly International)
> While Loraine James was working on her acclaimed 2021 LP Reflections, Loraine James filed away several songs that would ultimately make up her self-titled album, Whatever The Weather. On this meteorology-themed album, James did away with her club sound completely to write a series of ambient tracks distinguished by a worn, melancholy beauty. Here, intermittent rain is depicted as a flurry of lustrous synths, "14°C" is transformed into pensive arpeggios—the playfully jagged IDM she's revered for—and sounds hiccup and stop-start across placid pads all over the LP. As an artist whose main project emphasises tricky beats over strikingly subdued terrain, her pivot to producing a downtempo record—and doing it so well—makes perfect sense. -K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Soichi Terada - Asakusa Light (Rush Hour Music)
> Before this album, Japan's deep house don hadn't released a full-length in over 25 years. But it's abundantly clear that he hasn't lost his touch. There's a light, almost weightless, feel to this 11-track LP as the Tokyo composer and producer shows off his mastery of twinkling chords, spacey disco grooves, vintage synth patterns and video game sounds. Asakusa Light is relatively sparse—even its big-room tracks like "Bamboo Fighter" feature relatively minimal arrangements—which allows his signature melodies to really shine. Graceful and flowing, this is an album that celebrates Terada's craft without feeling like a pastiche of his '90s discography. -N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Marcel Dettmann - Fear Of Programming (Dekmantel)
> Marcel Dettmann has always earned more attention for his DJing than his productions, but real fans know that his discography is a treasure trove of dark, detailed techno. Fear Of Programming, which lands on the all-purpose Dekmantel label, is something different: bright, vibrant, even a little funny (thanks to a vocal guest spot from fellow Berghain resident Ryan Elliott). Fear Of Programming is loaded with bold, bassy techno and arresting ambient passages. The real gold is in the hooks, which the spartan but still powerful production emphasizes like a gold frame around a masterpiece painting. It's the work of someone who knows techno inside-out, and knows how to make it compelling without going too far outside the box. -A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Hagan - Textures (Python Syndicate)
> With his debut album Textures, the South London DJ and producer Hagan celebrates the intersecting cultures close to his heart with rich, percussion-driven music. Organic flourishes (Ghanaian group chants, windswept koras and sunny guitar lines, to name a few) broaden the horizons of his historically urban sound palette, and he truly comes into his own as an all-around songwriter. With expertly curated vocal collaborations that reflect on family and faith, elements of gqom, amapiano and highlife, Textures is a transportive ode to the drumming continent, and the meaning of growing up both within and away from it. One moment you're in a lush, jungly landscape, the next you're hustling in the streets of Accra. Textures is more than just African dance music; it's a vibrant amalgamation of all the ingredients and influences that make Brendan Ware Hagan. -Emeka.Okonkwo. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Deepchord - Functional Designs (Soma Records)
> All of Deepchord's records are good—all of them—but a few are extra special. Functional Designs falls into this category. On first glance, it's not all that different from his countless other LPs. You've got gaseous dub techno beats echoing out into a painstakingly woven web of field recordings, sure. But the melodies are bigger, the drums are heavier and, most importantly, the tracks are separate, each with its own hook, its own uniquely staggered rhythm. Creating another noir-ish world of rainy-night ambiance, Functional Designs is one of Deepchord's most approachable and immersive LPs, gently refurbishing the rock solid formula of dub techno that the Detroit artist has relied on for decades. -A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Björk - Fossora (One Little Independent)
> Björk spent a lot of time dancing and thinking about mushrooms during lockdown. From this—a time she described to Pitchfork as her "fungus period"—came Fossora, the Icelandic vanguard's tenth album. Björk has been making music for over three decades now, and with each record she steps into mystical, uncharted territory, creating work which is ever more beguiling, more avant-garde and always, somehow, even more Björk. On Fossora, Björk sings with a sweeping gravitas over rich woodwinds and distorted gabber beats, the additional instrumentation dancing around her vocal as she muses on the circle of life, nature and her own late mother. Digging her fingers into the earth, Björk unknots tributaries of tangled roots, the crashing drum patterns and complex textures representing the stark, breathtaking topography of her homeland. -Katie Thomas Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Huerco S. - Plonk (Incensio)
> From the first three seconds of Plonk, you know Huerco S. isn't doing the misty ambient thing again. Plucked strings ping in various directions, like popcorn exploding in a pan. Or, to be more accurate, like parts of a car yawning into gear. The automotive-inspired album, his first in six years, takes the American artist's sound to strange and innovative places—new sounds, unexpected textures, a first-ever vocal cameo. Isn't this what great artists do? Evolve, take left turns and, crucially, always deliver. -C.H. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Kode9 - Escapology (Hyperdub)
> Britain has never felt so close to collapse as it did in 2022. Between prime minister jockeying, mini-budgets and a volatile currency, Steven Goodman returned as Kode9 with a record that made the perfect accompaniment for the instability of the modern UK landscape. Written to accompany an experimental video game about Scotland leaving the union, Escapology operates along a dual axis, at once anxious—filled with eerie bits of sci-fi chatter and dense layers of swelling feedback—but also hopeful, at least when he turns to club tracks. "Uncoil," for example, is a pearl half-covered in sand somewhere between drum & bass and footwork, while "Cross The Gap" uses the negative space of dub to create something glimmering in the weight of the darkness around it. -Henry Ivy Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### DJ Lag - Meeting With The King (Ice Drop)
> After years pushing the Durban scene and helping to make the sound a global sensation, anticipation for DJ Lag's debut album, Meeting With The King, was sky-high. He used the opportunity to champion his community instead of his own glory, creating a record that is collaborative from start to finish, with a majority focus on artists hailing from his home country of South Africa. Meeting With The King takes the moody sonics of the gqom—born from township house parties—and makes it polished, opulent, even melodic, honouring the origins of the sound while adding catchy elements of amapiano, house, Afrotech and more. The title is boastful, but it's not wrong—on Meeting With The King, DJ Lag stakes his claim and continues his ascent, taking his musical family along for the ride. -K.T. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify

### Schacke - Apocalyptic Decadence (Instruments Of Discipline)
> Martin Schacke—of "Kisloty People" fame—has a knack for writing a hook. And almost every track of his debut album is decadent and addictive, loaded with catchy melodies. While the first half of the release gestures towards new beat and EBM—"Miasma Of Filth" and "Tasteless Passion" both pull from a lineage of tinny 808s and mid-tempo industrial—the second half offers grade-A techno-pop made for the the dance floor. Songs like "Body Type" and "Dungeon Crawler" are deceptively simple production-wise, but their repetitive choruses are the stuff that makes crossover hits. It's easy to imagine waiting for the train in the early morning hours after the rave, deliriously looping these brash three-note motifs again and again through your head. -Chloe Lula Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Ron Trent presents WARM - What Do The Stars Say To You (Night Time Stories)
> Ron Trent's WARM project captures it all in the name. As the Chicago house genius has advanced in his career, he's slowly luxuriated into a silky fusion sound that plucks from jazz, Balearic and soft rock in the spirit of carefully considered collaborators, like Texan psych-rock trio Khruangbin or Italian ambient composer Gigi Masin. "Admira," for instance, unfurls alongside loose bongo drums like a satisfying slow yawn after a midday slumber. Dappled sunlight patchworks "Flos Potentia," bound together by strumming bass guitar, and "On My Way Home," an earnest, jazzy sonic panacea for the oft-jaded ennui of modern music. After a long 11 years away from the format, Trent's latest album is a gorgeous evolution to behold. -W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Jamal Moss - Thanks 4 The Tracks U Lost (Modern Love)
> Jamal Moss, under his own name and as Hieroglyphic Being, is one of the defining forces in Chicago dance music. Whether he's making jacking house, experimental noise or blown-out techno, his work is defined by its sense of pure energy as he whips his machines into a frenzy. You'll find plenty of that rawness on his first LP for Modern Love, but where Thanks 4 The Tracks U Lost stands apart is in its surprising tenderness. Don't get me wrong—the drums have plenty of edge, and Moss still pushes his synthesizers to their breaking points—but the record is strikingly wistful, making for one of the most beautiful and tenderhearted of the many albums he's released. -H.I. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Beast Nest - Sicko (Ratskin Records)
> In their work as an organiser and mediator, Beast Nest, AKA Sharmi Basu, believes that healing should be a communal effort. The process for making Sicko could be described as a collective effort. The LP was recorded in the years following 2016's tragic Ghost Ship fire, which ended up killing 36 people in an unlicensed warehouse. Sicko was an integral part of their healing journey as a survivor. There's palpable catharsis written into the energetic pulse of the album, which bleeds several genres into a satisfyingly cohesive mix that makes it difficult to discern where one song ends and another begins. Ambient sequences with knotty sections that twinkle and flutter turn into spaced out dub and then, somewhere along the way, listeners are transported to post-punk-leaning IDM. The songs sprawl out slowly, but capped at six tracks, the LP is actually quite short, emblematic of the slowness of grief and the unpredictable, dynamic moments that accompany it. -K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Sudan Archives - Natural Brown Prom Queen (Stones Throw)
> Sudan Archives has always been a jewel of eccentricity. On her boundless second album, Natural Brown Prom Queen, rewind-worthy lyrics, maximalist experimentation (and what might be the most beat switches per song this year) coalesce into one remarkable document of self-empowerment and discovery. She embodies both her inner child and the person she's becoming ("I just wanna build LEGOs / I just wanna build, let's go"), all while keeping her signature sultriness dialed up to the max. Even putting her signature violin to the sidelines doesn't distract from her unique songwriting style. By the time she brings it home on the closer, "#513," she's delivered a defiant manifesto of hedonism, joy and femininity that raises the bar when it comes to post-genre pop music. -E.O. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Tanya Tagaq - Tongues (Six Shooter)
> Amid an ongoing reckoning with Canada's own history of indigenous genocide, Inuk artist Tanya Tagaq's sixth album approaches this legacy with righteous fury and surprising tenderness. An extension of a book of verse of the same name, Tongues takes stock of decades of violence and its effects on the bodies and minds of a people, but also recognizes the power one can possess in even the most hopeless of circumstances. Combining her traditional throat singing with English words wielded like daggers, it's a disarming and personal listen that makes the historical personal, underlining the scale of a tragedy but also the resilience and power of those who have survived it. -A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Steffi - The Red Hunter (Candy Mountain)
> For the past five years, Steffi has been refining a style of electro that sits somewhere between bruising club weaponry and crystalline IDM sound design. The Red Hunter broadens this palette to include touches of hip-hop and contemporary club music, while keeping the nuts and bolts of classic Detroit in place. The result is the best full-length of her career. On The Red Hunter she creates a singular cosmology where strange, stuttering drum patterns emerge underneath windswept melodies and contracting basslines. But even as she moves into far-flung realms, she never loses sight of the club, and almost every single one of these tracks would make a head-turning standout in a DJ set—which is what we've always come to Steffi for in the first place. -H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Mall Grab - What I Breathe (Looking For Trouble)
> In just a few years, Mall Grab went from master of a niche to king of everything. His debut album is a Chemical Brothers-sized crossover behemoth, attacking every form of radio-friendly dance music, from big room house to pounding jungle. It's inspired by the sounds of his adopted home of London, and to his credit, it captures what makes the city so enduring in dance music history. A restless blend of sound system culture, American and European imports and the kind of vocal hooks you hear on BBC Radio 1—with a few vocal turns from the man himself—it transforms Mall Grab from bedroom producer into something closer to a pop star. -A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Dopplereffekt - Neurotelepathy (Leisure System)
> Gerald Donald and To-Nhan Le Thi of Dopplerekkeft's second LP, like many 2022 albums, emerged from the toils of pandemic-induced isolation. The album's accompanying press text loftily asserts that its ten tracks are "considerations of the machine-human interface" and "transformative mental, psychological and transgenerational states." While some of these (perhaps overwrought) academic themes come through in the album's titles, it mostly sounds like the duo's mood piece-like electro fare—in the best possible way. The tracks throughout Neurotelepathy aren't predictable arrangements made for club play. They're spare and considered, making exquisite use of spatial sound design, spectral percussion and arpeggiated melodies. Some songs, like "EEG," take more than a minute to settle into a more legible song structure, but their expertly rendered craftsmanship make them worth the wait. -C.L. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### 700 Bliss - Nothing To Declare (Hyperdub)
> Spoken word and darbuka drums join in holy matrimony on this joint album from 700 Bliss—Philadelphia-based Moor Mother and DJ Haram. As the first full-length work from the duo after a series of collaborative EPs, Nothing To Declare sees the two artists claiming their matriarchal stake in electronic music. Haram's frenetic electronics speak in dialogue with Moor Mother's throaty vocals, delivered with a potent urgency. "Things ain't been the same since they put the lynch on us / water thicker than blood they convinced us," Ayewa opines. She's always been fearless in her delivery, but it's Muzeyyen's jagged productions that drive the point home. -W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### ABADIR - Mutate (SVBKVLT)
> SVBKVLT became one of the most important club music labels by showcasing the vital Shanghai club scene, though the label's purview has expanded and only become more vibrant in the process. Case in point: this LP from Cairo producer ABADIR, which combines a freewheeling style of jungle with Arabic rhythms. This is music that sounds permanently out of breath, feeding off its own excitable energy. Inspired by maqsoum music and the humid bustle of the Egyptian capital, Mutate features impossibly funky beats shrouded in thick field recordings and melodies that hang in the air like smog. It's a vision of the kind of global club music that SVBKVLT has always championed, and one of the best records in a catalogue that constantly ups the ante for where club music can go next. -A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Batu - Opal (Timedance)
> According to the International Gem Society, an opal is "distinctly individual"—more so than any other gemstone. The 3D-rendered opal on the cover of Batu's debut album is just that: a unique kaleidoscope of colours. Icy blue, vibrant green and a hot, lava red contrast with the grey underside of the opal and the moody background. Examining Opal's cover gives a strong sense of the sounds within. 11 tracks of sharp (though sometimes soft), complex and unpredictable electronic sculptures, a world of intricate sound design that Batu said he intended to feel vivid and transportive. Like so many LPs released this year, Opal is a lockdown record, made when Batu was in an introspective and contemplative state of mind, experimenting with moving away from club 12-inches and into a space more vulnerable and experimental. -K.T. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### FKA twigs - Caprisongs (Young)
> Caprisongs was one of the first RA Recommends of the year, and it was no surprise to many of us that it lingered long enough in our minds to make this end of year list. The album is brighter than anything we'd heard from twigs before. Gone is the operatic austerity of MAGDALENE. Instead, Caprisongs is a pop album with a capital P. The album mines from Afrobeats, grime, baile funk and R&B. It also sources from her personal life via snippets of conversations she recorded with loved ones. The immersive world she creates here deals with insecurity, "stupid boys" and friendship, but it's also celebratory. The world had opened up, after all. Twigs might have had a cry now and then, but at least she was doing it on the dance floor in the album's first single, "Tears In The Club.". As phenomenal as Caprisongs is, it's somehow even more impressive because it was pulled off with a welcome sense of humour. The album title, for example, is inspired by astrology—her "stubborn Caprisun ass telling her to work through the pain." Listeners can even eavesdrop on an astrological reading by the album's close. Sometimes, a little stubbornness is worth it. -K.M. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

## [The Best Mixes of 2021](https://ra.co/features/3952)
Date: 2021-12-22T13:00:01.000Z

### Presents: Eargoggles (Theo Parrish)
> "There are no genres. Nope, there's none. It's all tune for tune," Theo Parrish said outside the familiar NTS stall in Dalston's Gillett Square. And he doesn't just talk to talk. Many DJs claim to play across genres, but there are "many DJs" and then there is Theo Parrish. Over the past few years, the historically private artist has given fans a near-unprecedented view into his creative mind, first with the lengthy and unclassifiable sonic essay-meets-radio drama We Are All Georgeous Monsterss, and then this year with a six-and-a-half hour mix for NTS called "Eargoggles." (Parrish also dropped another six-hour mix close to press time.) Eargoggles is a marathon celebration of the infinite diversity of Black music, spanning from hard bop to hip-hop, searing psych rock to roots reggae. No random grab bag, this is a grand narrative and the revelation of a modern canon of soul with appearances by James Brown, The Congos and D'Angelo. The mix is an education unto itself—around hour five Parrish drops "Jazz Cats Part 1," a cut consisting of Madlib breathlessly laying out his key jazz influences—yet it's also a generous statement of purpose bursting with joy and urgency. 25 years into his career, Parrish gives us an exhaustive guide to the music that makes him tick, that has informed his own enduring classics. But why now? He explains the gravity of his convictions in the final moment of the magisterial "Eargoggles" mix: I'm hoping that at some point during this... After you've had a ride, a musical ride with me, that you take a moment to consider the troubles that you have, and consider that you're lucky to have them. Even if it doesn't affect you demographically, you should seriously consider the fact that there's an urgency that should be lived, in respect for those that get taken from us early under the guise of 'serve and protect.' So let's survive together. But let's remember them together as well. Let's not forget how we treat each other when the music's playing and how things change when the lights go on and we all go back to the rest of our lives. Let's go back with a little more urgency and care for the fellow man. Let's give a damn a little bit. And if we can do that, we got a better place.—Matt McDermott

### BIS Radio Show #1085 (Tim Sweeney)
> Over the past 21 years, Tim Sweeney never missed a week on the WNYU airwaves, hosting generations of DJs in the college station's basement studios. Beats In Space became iconic over this decades-long stretch, with Sweeney joining a grand tradition of New York radio DJs that also includes Shep Pettibone, Tony Humphries, Stretch and Bobbito, who held sway and influence far beyond the five boroughs. Though Sweeney has since brought Beats In Space back via Apple Music, last March he unexpectedly wrapped up his term on WNYU with episode #1085. Listeners flooded the comment section on a YouTube livestream after the news broke, thanking him for his illustrious tenure. For the finale, Sweeney played Beats In Space classics that highlighted the show's connection to the history of New York City dance music, dropping in an eclectic selection from Alicia Myers, Chaz Jankel and Arnold Jarvis. Full of hope, the two-and-a-half hours imparts a heartfelt message of gratitude to dedicated listeners and guests alike.—M.M.

### borshch mix 26 (Crystallmess)
> We're in the age of the polymath musician, and Crystallmess is the epitome. The French-born Ivorian and Guadeloupean DJ, producer and mixed media artist (who has shown her work at the Centre Pompidou and the Geneva Biennale, as well as playing at hallowed institutions like Berghain), has steadily made her way into the art and electronic music vanguards simultaneously. For her entry in the Borshch Magazine series, Crystallmess uses the mix format to express the social whiplash of lockdowns and reopenings, all the while showing off her agile genre-agnosticism. She includes edits of beloved Lil Wayne and Aaliyah tracks, blown-out jungle sampling "Ready or Not" by The Fugees, swirled with a heavy-handed dose of otherworldly ambient to evoke the expansive solitude of pandemic isolation.—Whitney Wei

### Lost In Dreams (Irini)
> Lost In Dreams was another entry in the growing SoundCloud archive of Traumprinz's resplendent multiverse. Irini, one of the elusive artist's many pseudonyms, trots out over three hours worth of new material, charting a comprehensive course in sensitive dance music from someone who creates at a relentless pace. Unlike some of his other aliases, irini doesn't have a unique sound in the way that DJ Healer or the Prince Of Denmark do, but that's also what makes this mix so rewarding. The dub techno, UK garage, even minimal house productions spring forth from an enigmatic source, keeping the intrigue of listening alive. Now it's just a matter of waiting for the inevitable vinyl releases.—Henry Ivry

### ETCHED 003 (Live Set) (Wata Igarashi)
> A live set from techno's undisputed master of arpeggios, Wata Igarashi, is a special thing no matter where it takes place: dark basements or—why not—the Nobeyama Radio Observatory. Located in Yatsugatake, Japan, the observatory has been a hub for radio astronomy research since 1982. Its imposing rows of satellites and telescopes, set against a beautiful landscape, provide an almost too-good-to-be-true backdrop for Igarashi's cosmic, otherworldly sound. Beautifully shot on video by ETCHED (an audiovisual project showcasing domestic artists), the set plunges into the outer reaches of Igarashi's unmistakable productions, reworking previous records and some unreleased material into an hour-long trip that remains one of 2021's most memorable techno sets.—Richard Akingbehin

### 100% UNRELEASED OSSX MIX (OSSX)
> For many of us, New Jersey group OSSX's "Split Wig" on Allergy Season was one of the year's indisputable anthems. And the only thing better than just one track is a whole hour of exclusive material. 100% UNRELEASED OSSX is a goldmine for anyone into big drums and even bigger melodies (with a "Split Wig" appearance early on). There's a light-footed touch to breakbeats, plus some nimble choppage and a parade of brazen, uplifting edits that sample a tongue-in-cheek gamut: Modjo to Janet Jackson to September's Eurodance hit "Cry For You." It's that "Are they really doing this? Sampling that?" swagger that cinches this mix as one of our endlessly replayable favorites this past year.—Andrew Ryce

### TTT Mixtape (Josey Rebelle)
> Josey Rebelle could—and probably will, honestly—make this list every year for the foreseeable future, and it would be nothing short of deserved. The UK DJ is one of the best selectors on the planet, with a record digger's taste but a party-rocker's ear. She'll play obscure records, sure, but they'll never feel obscure. Her mix, first released as a very limited tape on The Trilogy Tapes in April, is a perfect example of this, stitching together slow jams, weirdo techno and even snippets of radio play, with a darker edge than what we're used to from some of Rebelle's recent mixes. The eventual streaming upload of the mix was greeted with the fervor of an album drop, and for good reason: this TTT Mix strums the eclectic but intuitive thread that’s tied through all of her sets. The only flaw is that it isn't twice as long.—A.R.

### GHOSTCAST 014 (DESYN)
> In certain circles, the name Desyn Masielo commands a kind of reverence, and the London lifer has been blending the finest never-on-YouTube Discogs gems for the past two decades. Here, Masiello flaunts those deep-digging DJ tendencies with wild abandon. Ghostcast14, recorded live at Hoppetosse, is a good intro to what he can achieve when he goes for the jugular from the very beginning. We start in medias res with UK garage basslines, but his masterful pacing and mixing means that before we know it, we're zipping through starry rave, acidic electro, '90s house and just about everything else under the sun. For us mortal trainspotters, the only thing worse than having missed this party is that we'll likely never know what any of these records are.—H.I.

### Daisychain 154 (DJ Fart In The Club)
> DJ Fart In The Club (AKA Soyoon Choi) certainly has an offbeat sense of humor, but when it comes to their DJ sets, they're entirely straight-faced. Even though this set came in at the tail end of last year, it still banged all the way through into 2021. The Berlin artist unleashes a sticky hour-and-a-half of acid-tinged wobblers, prog house and freaky trance for the Chicago-based, women and non-binary focused podcast series Daisychain. In the knottier sections, Choi takes listeners on a jaunt full of vertiginous peaks and deep valleys by roving into spiraling wormholes of techno, garage and preternatural club music.—Kiana Mickles

### sit on my interface (1/2) (CCL)
> In the weeds of the first 20 minutes of CCL's sit on my interface mix, it's easy to presume that this is a fully ambient offering. But that would be a hasty judgement, as once it approaches the one-hour mark, the energy intensifies with such careful, gradual restraint that even the active listener might wonder how they even got to this point. Sure enough, the mix ultimately reaches a dark, slinky plateau with a bubbling, percussive roller and then rockets off from there. "sit on my interface (2/2)" can't arrive soon enough.—K.M.

## [The Best Tracks of 2021](https://ra.co/features/3951)
Date: 2021-12-21T00:47:34.000Z

### Overmono - So U Kno (Poly Kicks)
> 2021 felt like Overmono's breakthrough year. Each new release of theirs seemed to outdo the last, from the euphoric rave of "Pieces Of 8" to their pitch-perfect fabric mix to the peppy garage of "Diamond Cut" (one of the major highlights from what was arguably the year's best Essential Mix). But it was "So U Kno," released not on the duo's usual home of XL Recordings but on their own, smaller Poly Kicks imprint, that made it into what felt like every DJ set of the post-reopening world. Like so much of Overmono's recent work, there's a whiff of a bygone, post-dubstep era to "So U Know." Built around an unforgettable vocal chop, "So U Kno" is the kind of track that elicits cheers from a dance floor the minute the DJ starts to mix it in. It has one of those in-between beats—kind of house, kind of 2-step, kind of techno—and a thrill-ride of a breakdown. Encapsulating the frenzied, overjoyed vibe of the summer's post-reopening clubbing with a hint of wistful nostalgia, "So U Kno" perfectly sums up this year's excitement and radical ups and downs.—Andrew Ryce Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Billie Eilish - Oxytocin (Interscope Records)
> Hidden in the middle of Billie Eilish's intimate, often confessional singer-songwriter album is one of the year's biggest, loudest club tracks: the pop megastar's equivalent of Nine Inch Nails' "Closer." "Cause I like to do things God wouldn't approve of / If she saw us," Eilish whispers over a clanging, outsized beat. "Oxytocin" takes the tactile, goosebump-inducing approach of Eilish's other records and blows it up to a macro scale. It's the sound of being cornered in the club, pushed towards the speaker until all you can hear are the kick drums.—A.R. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Elvin T - Get Close (Regraded)
> Throw a jacking house rhythm underneath the right vocal and soaring strings, and you've found yourself a tried and true way to excite a dance floor. There is nothing radical or even innovative about Elvin T's "Get Close," which hews closely to this time-honored formula, but there doesn't need to be. The Philadelphia producer laced together the perfect combination of driving percussion, vocals, a glossy string loop and a couple of breakdowns. Released as the final record on Midland's Regraded label at the start of summer, the track's timing was also fortuitous as dance floors got busier over the summer. —Henry Ivry Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### PinkPantheress - Just for me (Parlophone)
> TikTok made PinkPantheress one of the year's defining pop stars. She became a musical sensation just for releasing snippets of songs on the video app before the full versions appeared on streaming services. Anyone who hadn't heard of PinkPantheress probably did when she finally released the music video for "Just for me," an early '00s-inspired visual depicting her on a studio stage with a sulky crew of emo kids. The Mura Masa co-produced track nodded to garage and early '00s pop-rock, perfectly encapsulating "new nostalgic," a term PinkPantheress uses to describe her own sound. If the lyrics—which follow a stalker's infatuation with a crush—are unsettling, it's intentional. The song was inspired by the obsessive themes that run through Eminem's "Stan," and is more a practice in dramatic storytelling than a portrayal of real-life events. Much like the rest of her catalog, which is tailor-made for bright-eyed Gen Z TikTokers with short attention spans and a love for danceable, snappy hooks, "Just for me" hovers around two minutes in length—just long enough to make you want to press rewind and hear it all over again.—Kiana Mickles Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Planetary Assault Systems - Say It Loud (Token)
> As Planetary Assault Systems, Luke Slater makes huge, no-bullshit techno. There's plenty of technical wizardry going on, sure, but you know what to expect: thunderdome kick drums and synths that sound like sonar pings. Enter "Say It Loud," the highlight from Belgian label Token's 100th release, which subverts Slater's historical output with a goofy sound that matches its goofy title (right down to the deadpan vocal repeating "say it loud"). Refreshing and zippy, it sounds a bit like Slater poking fun at the current crop of big-time techno producers, then beating them at their own game with a track that's over-the-top, funky and absolutely monstrous.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud / Spotify / Soundcloud

### tondiue - Painted Creature (secondnature)
> tondiue's debut packed an album's worth of ideas into an EP of techno that explores the outer reaches of the genre, specifically slowed-down breakbeats and tunneling, Wata Igarashi-style arpeggio workouts. "Painted Creature" falls somewhere between these styles. What starts out as a loose hand percussion workout laced with clipped, unnerving vocal samples before the breakdown turns it into a tripped-out big room techno cut that could stand up with the best of 'em. It's just one of many highlights on a techno EP that sticks with us like few others have this year.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Nia Archives - Headz Gone West (HIJINXX)
> Drum & bass was all over pop and R&B this year, though it rarely sounded as heavy and convincing as it did on Nia Archives' Headz Gone West, where the London singer peppers expert breakbeat chop-ups with jazzy vocal runs. The title track is an easy highlight, packing a whole lot into just over two minutes as Nia Archives sings about her anxiety, her wandering mind and getting "high just to pass the time" over beats that crest and wane like lashing ocean waves.—A.R. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

### Stef Mendesidis - Stalker (Klockworks)
> Like his first EP for Ben Klock's label in 2019, Greek born, Kyiv-based producer Stef Mendesidis' Klockworks 33 delivered four irresistibly catchy, full-pelt techno tracks when it came out in October. "Stalker" is by far the most elegant cut of the batch, threading delicate hats and a single, sonorous pad in and out of an arpeggiated bassline that opens and closes over the course of five-and-a-half minutes. Like Klock, Mendesidis has mastered the art of functional peak-time techno that feels anthemic despite its simplicity.—Chloe Lula Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Logic1000 - I Won't Forget (Therapy)
> Logic1000's "I Won't Forget" had unfortunate timing, landing at the very beginning of the year when most of the world was still shut down. It has all the makings of a festival hit with its deliciously heavy slo-mo breakbeat and moody synths that come in halfway through the track, like tears blurring your peripheral version. Just when you think you have the track pegged down, everything falls away to reveal a truly evil-sounding Reese bassline that pushes it to another level. In all, it's a wonderful, canny fusion of UK dance music styles from a talented Australian producer.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### John Glacier - If Anything (PLZ Make It Ruins)
> "If Anything" producer and Frank Ocean collaborator Vegyn originally found John Glacier's music on SoundCloud, but the London-based artists quickly realized they'd met before, gravitating towards each other to chat at the back of parties. It's appropriate, then, that "If Anything," the opening salvo from Glacier's debut album, brims with the swooning disorientation of a big night out. Over a triumphant, boom bap-influenced beat, Glacier raps in impressionistic turns of phrase: "Starlight, dancin' in the moon / I'm ravin' rabbit, I'm on shroom." "If Anything" introduces a visionary and arty MC with an instantly recognizable banger.—Matt McDermott Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### KG - Koko feat. Mista Silva (Black Acre)
> Karen Nyame KG earned the nickname "The Goddess of Rhythm" for her intricate UK funky productions, but the British-Ghanaian artist's biggest track to date came when she stepped up to the mic. "Koko" was an immediate summer hit that benefited from a magpie's approach to recent African dance music innovations. In just under three minutes, Nyame mixes airy highlife guitar, Afrobeats and amapiano. Her vocal, meanwhile, is unapologetically carnal: "Don't waste my time / I wanna bust down, bust down / Go rounds, go rounds / lights out, lights out." Modern dance music often feels like it's designed for some airless dungeon. By comparison, "Koko" feels like sex on the beach.—M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Koreless - Joy Squad (Young)
> It's safe to say the Welsh producer Koreless got a little in his head while working on his debut album, which was almost a decade in the making. The time enabled him to do endless revisions and embark on creative soul-searching that eventually paid off. The LP's ten tracks display extraordinary sonic detail and inventiveness. "Joy Squad" sticks out as a granular reimagining of a big room anthem. Chopped-up shards of melody and vocals combine with cinematic strings in a kaleidoscopic funhouse of a track that would be overwhelming if it wasn't so concise.—M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Maxwell Sterling - Decay Time (AD 93)
> Turn Of Phrase reveals Maxwell Sterling as a rare talent, remarkably adept in both electronic sound design and orchestral arrangement. While the title track flabbergasts with a mix of furious classical runs and Autechre-level sound processing, the brief "Decay Time" is the record's centrepiece. While the drums clearly hearken back to IDM's '90s heyday, the track's plinking synth bass and strings converge to evoke a sense of deep lament. This difficult balance of head-spinning programming and lilting emotionality recalls classics within the genre like Aphex Twin's "Flim."—M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

### DJ Black Low & Kapzela feat. Licy Jay & MLG - Emonate Oe Bethela D Vosho (Awesome Tapes From Africa)
> Considering house and techno are inventions of the African diaspora, it feels like poetic justice that some of the most innovative changes happening in modern electronic music are emerging from the continent. In recent years, amapiano's log drum grooves have sprung from Gauteng townships to clubs around the world. DJ Black Low, the 20-year-old amapiano producer signed to Awesome Tapes From Africa, brought an experimental edge to the young genre on his 2021 album, Uwami. On "Emonate Oe Bethela D Vosho," Black Low works with Kapzela and the MCs Licy Jay & MLG to forge a groove that's as urgent as it is inviting.—M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Currency Audio - Modus Choperandi (Exit Records)
> Photek's 1997 hit "Modus Operandi" brought together the best parts of trip-hop, jazz, jungle and hip-hop. Consisting mostly of drums and atmospheric effects, it redefined drum & bass and celebrated the art of percussion itself. On his entirely improvised tribute to the track, Rajeev Maddela pulled from Photek's beat science, fusing recreated '90s breakbeats with live drumming and his own signature sound. Maddela's razor-sharp instrumentation—accentuated by ghostly pads—brought new depths to jazzy drum & bass this year.—Nyshka Chandran Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Max Watts - Hipnautic (Self-released)
> Only recently exiting his teenage years, rising techno prodigy Max Watts has released some of the freshest renditions of Detroit techno this year. His self-described "post-Detroit" style is unique for its raw, improvisational flow, channeling the freewheeling energy of Midwestern techno greats like Underground Resistance, Claude Young and DJ Rush. Watts's sincere investment in the emotion and groove behind his music makes way for some of the purest and most exuberant modern techno around. One of the hits off April's MW002 EP, "Hipnautic," was a favorite for its lurching percussion, drunken, loopy melody and dissipating hi-hats. Watts knows how to build and retract momentum in all the right places.—K.M. Listen: Bandcamp

### Bapari - Daybreak (Self-released)
> The "Ha" stab, a rousing "crash" sample that typically falls on the 4, is to ballroom music as vocal chops are to Jersey club. They're classic hallmarks of the genres—once you hear them, it's difficult to mistake what you're listening to. The key elements of ballroom music, a style intrinsically tied to its dance culture, have understandably caught the eye of numerous club producers in recent years.
