And Bapari, a Brooklyn-based artist whose music draws from all manner of East Coast club styles, is one of the latest to be inspired. On the title track of their Daybreak EP, the "Ha" stab, rather than assuming its traditional role of accentuating the melody, becomes the melody across a frenzy of playful, whip-sawing crashes. Offering some respite, Bapari skillfully tempered the track with plenty of space and the occasional murmuring vocal that floats off into the ether.—K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Ayesha - Potential Energy (Scuffed Recordings)
> There are a few simple but essential ingredients needed to make the perfect Ayesha track: nimble percussion, intoxicatingly psychedelic melodies and plenty of focus on the low-end. "Potential Energy" nails all three. The first gobsmacking moment arrives with synths that ripple with the intensity of an ultraviolet wave. Then the first acid lead slithers in, a portent of the brilliance to come: a rip-roaring showcase of lumbering breakbeats and off-kilter synths, replete with Saturday morning cartoon sound effects. It's a certified energy-boosting weapon for DJs on the late-late shift.—K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### A.G - always, you (Self-released)
> Breakout artist A.G not only has a penchant for creating robust, propulsive sounds, but she's got the bravura to back it up. Last year, the East London native postedMixmag's review of her August Discwoman selections, including the tongue-in-cheek caption "heavy-bodied means I'm thick." It's quips like these—and all the offerings on her donotdisturb EP—that shirk the stereotype of the introverted bedroom producer. In standout track "always, you," A.G demonstrates a magisterial command of UK drill, directing staccato hi-hats and pitched-up vocal samples to clamber over heavy bass uppercuts with a tenacity that matches her personality. When they say "confidence is everything," take this example as a case in point.—Whitney Wei Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify

### UNIIQU3 - Microdosing (Local Action)
> When Jersey club royalty holds court, the world pays attention. Cherise Gray, otherwise known as UNIIQU3, has been championing the 135 BPM club music of her Newark home on the international stage for the better part of a decade, and this year she really came into her own. "Microdosing," the lead single off her Heartbeats EP, delves into house, rap and four-to-the-floor big room beats: "Took a tab and tripped / Drown in it / Fall into my abyss / The sticky icky wet wet." Gray details a lysergic wet dream that climaxes at peak time on the dance floor. Synth-heavy and oozing with confidence, the track holds the hip-swinging sashay of a lip glossed, sugar-coated seduction—without the predictable box spring squeaks.—W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Blawan - Under Belly (XL Recordings)
> "Under Belly" has a little bit of everything that we've come to love about Jamie Roberts (AKA Blawan), from his early Hessle Audio days to his tech-wiz modular techno era. It also perfectly captures what has always been refreshing about his music: He never takes himself too seriously. With its groovy swing and ghost choir motif, "Under Belly" sounds like the most fun he's ever had on record. By looking back to his early days as an honorary post-dubstep protege, Roberts proves he can return to the past while still firmly developing his sound.—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Anz - Unravel In The Designated Zone (OTMI)
> Anz broke out in 2020, but her career has taken off in 2021. Between her yearly all-originals mixes and an increasingly hectic DJing and radio schedule, the Manchester artist knocked out two of the year's most exciting celebrations of UK club music. While her Ninja Tune debut All Hours was a masterclass in fusing pop with electro, UK garage and jungle, "Unravel In The Designated Zone" remains the year's high water mark. It's a bit more understated, but it still feels like an instant classic from the moment the song's lead synth begins howling over her signature off-kilter percussion.—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

### SHE Spells Doom - Rudnick (All Centre)
> There was plenty of genre-bending club music released this year, but Zambia-based SHE Spells Doom's release for All Centre was a hybrid like no other. The three-track EP showcased an impressive repertoire, crossing from UK funky to Afro house. But it was the confident swagger of "Rudnick" that kept clocking up the re-listens. The track's synth work has the technicolor polish of contemporary UK techno set over the stuttering swagger of '00s hip-hop percussion. Named for the sci-fi Oedipus anti-hero in the movie Heavy Metal, the track surpasses its namesake, creating a sense of noirish anxiety without losing sight of the funk.—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Maara - The Forbidden Plum (Isla)
> 2021 saw a new sound emanating from Canada's dance music underground led by labels like Planet Euphorique, Isla and Acting Press. No one captured this better than Maara and her sexually charged, trance-flecked take on techno and electro. Across two breakout EPs, there was a je ne sais quoi to the Montreal producer's often illicit but lighthearted tracks. Her best song, "The Forbidden Plum" from her Potion Activated EP, had elements of both. Dark, pulsing synth bleeps, a twisted metallic bassline and a prog house throwback gated vocal sit under a repeated refrain: "Want it so badly." "The Forbidden Plum" is a cocktail of hedonistic indulgence.—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp

### SHERELLE - 160 DOWN THE A406 (BEAUTIFUL)
> While SHERELLE expressed plenty of frustration over the pandemic in 2021—and even scolded the UK government in a broadcast for Newsnight—her debut EP was surprisingly light. The A-side, "160 Down The A406," is pure joy, featuring an airy chord progression, dreamy mallet melodies and chipmunk vocal cries all sewn into a breakbeat reverie. Although we can't in good faith recommend doing 160 MPH on the A406, we can put our weight behind this fuzzy footwork-jungle fusion, which showcases how SHERELLE can flex in the box just as much as she can behind the decks.—Emeka Okonkwo Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### MC Boing (Danny L Harle) - Boing Beat (Mad Decent)
> MC Boing is one of the four new aliases Danny L Harle uses on his debut album. With "Boing Beat," he channels early '00s happy hardcore with spellbinding results. As part of the LP's virtual club experience—a four-story rave complex called Harlecore—Harle's tributes border on parody at certain moments. But at others he stumbles upon gold. "Boing Beat" is unapologetic, E'd-up euphoria taken to unnatural highs with MC Boing's manic vocals and Hannah Diamond's girlish, synthetic hook.. While Boing's half-screamed deliveries can be jarring at times, with lyrics as wholesome as "Everyone here is safe and nice / Makes me wanna have a great life," how could we do anything but smile and dance?—E.O. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### LSDXOXO - Sick Bitch (XL Recordings)
> Between those buzzing synth lines and RJ Glasgow's robotic but commanding vocals, "Sick Bitch" by LSDXOXO could easily become this generation's "Satisfaction" by Benny Banassi. The Berlin-based producer and DJ pulled even fewer punches than usual on his XL Recordings debut, opting to go full thrust with lyrics so raunchy they'd leave a conservative news anchor on life support. Talk of testing gag reflexes and exploding in one's own clothes leaves nothing to the imagination and can put every room it's played in in an erotic headlock—or at least a sensual trance.—E.O. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Calibre & DRS v Mark Ernestus - Badder (Signature Records)
> Basic Channel cofounder Mark Ernestus made a relatively rare turn to the mixing console with "Badder," linking up with drum & bass legend Calibre to craft understated and moody dub techno. The song samples the original "Badman," featuring DRS, and subtly riffs on its name. Things get hypnotic as DRS's vocal chops ripple and echo through the mix, while a snare that threatens to land never does. All the while, hi-hats tick ominously like the second hand on a watch. The shadows loom larger in this dark makeover, a bass-heavy maze rife with riveting tension.—E.O. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Fiyahdred - Anyway (Do It) (Hyperdub)
> Press officers will tell you tunes are anthems when they're not. But Hyperdub wasn't messing around with "Anyway (Do It)." This club singalong is a blast of fresh air, blending gqom, amapiano and UK funky with an insanely catchy vocal about rolling spliffs and generally not giving a fuck. There's nothing more exciting than a new artist breaking through with absolute fire. On the strength of this banger and the rest of their excellent debut EP, 2022 could be a life-changing year for the burgeoning UK producer.—Carlos Hawthorn Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Jossy Mitsu - Ø (Astral Black)
> Two wins stand out for Jossy Mitsu in 2021: becoming a resident at London club fabric and releasing her debut EP, Planet J. The impressive thing about her productions is how they echo her DJ sets, distilling a love of dubstep, UK garage, techno and jungle into a fresh, convincing package. The pick of the bunch was "Ø," named after Hyperdub's groundbreaking London party. The track's title informed its contents: dark, slinky and dripping in wall-rattling UK energy.—C.H. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

## [The Best Albums of 2021](https://ra.co/features/3950)
Date: 2021-12-15T21:27:34.000Z

### Space Afrika - Honest Labour (Dais Records)
> Listening to Honest Labour feels like street lights burning onto tired retinas and long nights of feeling small in a big city. On their sophomore album, producers Joshua Inyang and Joshua Reid created a series of nocturnal meditations, a series of nineteen short tracks bleeding into one another, in tribute to their hometown of Manchester. The duo's instrumentation is replete with field recordings of urban white noise, balanced by resonant cellos, hazy guitars and spectral guest performances with fragments of profound conversations—as if overheard from the night before—resulting in the audio equivalent of subconscious dreamscape. Put simply by Inyang and Reid themselves, Honest Labour is "an album about love and loss." The track "Indigo Grit," for instance, abruptly ends just as the speaker is about to explain the difference between liking and loving someone—a fleeting snippet of wisdom lost just before listeners could grab hold of it. But as with any inquiries into life’s most existential questions, the artists weren't intending to arrive at any conclusions. Through their album, they embraced the sheer mystery of the human experience, remaining at the mercy of their emotions just like the rest of us.—Emeka Okonkwo Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### AceMoMA - A Future (Haus of Altr)
> AceMo and MoMA Ready have released a gob-stopping amount of music over the past few years, but their second album together, A Future, really put it all into perspective. The duo work in a well-worn transatlantic tradition, blending drum & bass, jungle and techno, but in their hands it feels cutting-edge as they jump from one tempo to the next with tangible excitement. In spite of its name, the album is the sound of the duo creating a better present, of reimagining Afrofuturist narratives to suit the here-and-now rather than a distant future, of AceMoMA paving the way for everyone around them in New York and beyond.—Andrew Ryce Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Eris Drew - Quivering In Time (T4T LUV NRG)
> After conquering the DJing circuit with a mix of psychedelic evangelism and irresistible old-school techno flair, Eris Drew started dipping her toes into production with vibrant results. On her debut album, Quivering In Time, she outdoes herself with nine tracks of club heat packing a festival-sized dose of euphoria into a retro sound palette of tight drum loops, breakbeats and dewy pads. She even includes a sample of psychonaut and ethnobotanist Terence McKenna to drive the point home. House music in 2021 hardly got much more ecstatic than this.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Emeka Ogboh - Beyond The Yellow Haze (A-TON)
> Is Beyond The Yellow Haze pretty funky for an art installation? Quite possibly. The original piece catalogs the sounds of bustling Lagos—car horns, traffic, chatter. Those recordings, made into an album for A-TON—Ostgut Ton’s art-forward sublabel—forms the foundation for ghostly broken techno that moves with the start-stop pulse of everyday life in the city. Ogboh's rich, layered atmospherics approximate fog and the motion blur of brake lights on a busy freeway, capturing the vibe of a city in the midst of immense growth, like a moment encased in amber.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Erika de Casier - Sensational (4AD)
> It's difficult to think of any other record this year that united more people from across different electronic music scenes than Sensational. Building on the Danish artist's Y2K R&B obsession and backed with lush yet subdued production from collaborator Central, it is a quiet storm of plucked strings, ornate piano and pitter-patter drums. De Casier's hushed voice alternates between vulnerable and sarcastic, full of biting phrases and memorable one-liners: "You gotta be polite if you wanna roll with me." It’s the kind of music that's made for both memorable dance floor moments and cryptic Instagram captions directed at you-know-who.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### George Riley - interest rates, a tape (Self-released)
> It's tempting to call George Riley an old soul given her use of R&B vocals over '90s-influenced jazzy breaks, but that wouldn't do justice to her first mixtape, which felt ambitious even at its most relaxed. Her words come out in a stream-of-consciousness blur, revealing and incisive in their casual, say-whatever-comes-to mind-flow ("I don't want any man / Full stop!"). Oliver Palfreyman's beats feel dynamic and fluid, as if tailored to every twist and turn in Riley's sinuous vocal melodies. Dark, uplifting and sometimes even funny, it is one of the most striking R&B debuts of the year—Afrofuturism tuned to a very personal frequency.—A.R. Listen: Spotify / Apple Music

### Hoavi - Invariant (Peak Oil)
> With Invariant, Hoavi set a new standard for what you might call ambient jungle. Combining the luxe atmospherics of dub techno, the fidgety pulse of footwork and the acrobatic loop-de-loops of jungle, the Russian producer's album is uncommonly beautiful, blowing minds while soothing them at the same time. You can pick any track at random and find something to obsess over—the breakcore-in-the-clouds of "Dver," the Balearic funk of "Streamline." But the LP is best taken as a whole, a wash of creamy chords and aerodynamic drum programming.—A.R. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Virtual Dreams: Ambient Explorations In The House & Techno Age, 1993-1997 (MUSIC FROM MEMORY)
> Landing at the very end of 2020, when so many of us were deep in another round of lockdowns, Music From Memory's Virtual Dreams compilation was practically made for daydreaming in your bedroom. Bringing together some of the finest downtempo cuts from both lesser-known names like MDA Analog and lesser-known projects from established names (like Move D and Roman Flügel), the compilation creates a half-lidded world where kick drums dreamily float in and out of focus. Virtual Dreams maps a time when the boundaries between electronic music for the club and the living room weren’t totally solidified, occupying a corridor space between the chill-out room and the dance floor. —Henry Ivry. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Various - The Sound Of Limo (Limousine Dream)
> Gene On Earth's The Sound of Limo compilation is a roster of the artists du jour of the new minimal scene, providing documentary evidence of a vital corner of the underground while also working surprisingly well as a cohesive album. Each producer gathered here, from Sugar Free to Dyed Soundorom, has their own quirks, but certain throughlines—chunky basslines, swung drums, cascading video game bleeps—define a sub-genre of a sub-genre unto themselves. The music here is club-ready tech house, but the flourishes of fluorescent synth and often wacky melodies make it as whimsical as it is functional.—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

### Skee Mask - Pool (Ilian Tape)
> Clocking in at over an hour and 45 minutes, Pool demanded a commitment to active listening when it dropped. But Skee Mask has always excelled in the album format, and the extended run time allowed him to cover more ground than ever before. Pool takes the plunge into the sui generis cannabis haze of its soundscapes, where Skee Mask put his love of ambient atmosphere and UK dance music into conversation with bits of soulful funk, jazz and some of his fastest tempos yet (Pool went north of the 170 Arctic Circle at points). But, as only Skee Mask can, he creates an immersive and singular trip where genres come second to the textural richness and detail of his soundscapes, which range from danceable to stop-you-in-your-tracks gorgeous—H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / SoundCloud

### Yu Su - Yellow River Blue (bié RECORDS)
> Yu Su's steady stream of dance-adjacent 12-inches over the past four years established a dusky and increasingly ornate twist on the Vancouver house sound, but her debut album Yellow River Blue took her somewhere entirely new, both figuratively and literally. The album functions both as a travel diary and love song. It documents a tour through her native China from Qingdao to the far-west city of Xining, recorded in different cities across the country where Yu Su both reconnected with her homeland and found a whole new community of electronic producers she was previously cut off from. The album is appropriately restless and exploratory, as Yu Su charts a path through geography and genres, from slo-mo breakbeat to Krautrock to dubby downtempo. —H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Perila - How Much Time It Is Between You And Me? (Smalltown Supersound)
> Aleksandra Zakharenko, alongside similar-minded artists like Ulla and Ben Bondy, makes ambient music that breaks the mold: it's not necessarily intended to bring you solace and definitely won't make an easy soundtrack for any hotel lobbies (or elevators). How Much Time It Is Between You And Me?, is just as unsettling and eerie as it is delicate. The album uses these mixed emotions—as well as touches of post-rock melodrama and angst—to create a liminal state between waking and dreaming held together by Zakharenko's voice, which guides you through labyrinths that can be nightmarish but, just as quickly, morph into luxurious daydreams. —H.I. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Andy Stott - Never The Right Time (Modern Love)
> It's been a decade since Andy Stott released the pair of EPs that introduced us to the dubby world of "knackered house." Since then, the UK artist's music has incorporated decaying memories of pop, like a ghostly outline caught in a photograph, through his ongoing collaborations with Alison Skidmore. Never The Right Time polished that rusting patina into Stott's most accessible album to date. "Don't Know How" is, by his standards, nearly bubblegum. This was true across the board on the record—even the abrasive mechanical rain of "Answers" ends with an uplifting, choral melody. Stott hasn’t lost his penchant for darkness, but now he isn’t afraid of contrasting it with bold and bright bursts of colour either.—H.I. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / SoundCloud

### Wanton Witch - Wanton Witch (Stroboscopic Artefacts)
> Stroboscopic Artefacts has been a hub for no-frills experimental techno for more than a decade, modeling itself in the restrained but psychedelic-friendly image of label owner Lucy. Following a year-long hiatus in 2020—after Lucy released a ten-year compilation of sleek dance floor cuts by mostly old guard artists—the label returned with the surprising self-titled LP from Bangkok-based Wanton Witch. The album opens a new chapter for Stroboscopic Artefacts, not only by featuring a queer, trans outsider artist, but by presenting a volatile, rave-adjacent sound palette beyond the label's wheelhouse. Wanton Witch dive-bombes and detonates with apocalyptic thuds and hardstyle drum fills, marking a new and exciting turn for the imprint and for Alegria's blossoming career. —Chloe Lula Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Dawn Richard - Second Line (Merge Records)
> Dawn Richard's sixth album—and first for the indie giant Merge—introduces her Afrofuturist alter ego, the golden, feather-plumed cyborg King Creole, who Richard described as an "assassination of stereotypes." Working Black-rooted genres like bounce and footwork into her usual experimental R&B, Richard balances a sense of play with her core strengths as a vocalist. "Bussifame" explodes with rallying whoops and commanding swagger, "Jacuzzi" aches with crooning sensuality, and "FiveOhFour (a lude)" switches to a braggadocious snarl. In tandem with intimate audio clips of her mother’s musings on love and Louisiana, it is a kaleidoscopic portrait of Richard's inner world and Southern heritage in glossy, florid detail. —Whitney Wei Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### L'Rain - Fatigue (Mexican Summer)
> L'Rain's second album meditates on the seismic complexities of a single emotion—grief—and its ability to exhaust and to destabilize, but to also spur personal evolution. Fatigue swoons into a tender revelry, both in terms of L'Rain's purring vocals and her warm, glowing productions, where the jangling piano keys and melancholic punctuation of saxophone dance around grainy sound recordings. It reminds listeners that sadness is so often site-specific. As a born-and-raised Brooklyner, L'Rain's singular blend of jazz, neo soul and ambient bears the heaviness of her urban environs on top of an already bruised psyche. —W.W. Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music / Soundcloud

### V/A - Amapiano Now (NTS)
> If anything's apparent from the past few years, it's that dance music is inherently political. The most exciting dance music genre in the world at the moment—amapiano—demonstrates this point in a strikingly literal manner. Born in the townships in Gauteng, South Africa, the fledgling post-kwaito genre is the sound of joy in the midst of struggle. Now it's sweeping the globe. Amapiano Now, the 16-track compilation from NTS, is a bluffer's guide to the new South African dance phenomenon. From established acts like Vigro Deep and Gaba Canal to upstarts like Teno Afrika, the Shannen SP and Joe Cotch-curated collection demonstrates the inherent mid-tempo sensuality of amapiano, the thrilling sound of a generation of artists discovering their powerful collective voice. —Matt McDermott Listen: Spotify / Soundcloud

### Floating Points, Pharoah Sanders & The London Symphony Orchestra - Promises (Luaka Bop)
> Reading over the personnel for Promises, one might expect a grandiose statement—a multigenerational spiritual jazz odyssey for the ages. Instead, Sam Shepherd and the legendary Pharoah Sanders show a staggering knack for subtlety. Building upon a searching motif of four seven-note chords, both Shepherd and Sanders play with extraordinary humility. The careful arrangements serve as a backdrop for Sanders' restrained sax soloing, but the record doesn’t headline one artist over the other. Instead it reaches for an ineffable oneness, the pinnacle of improvised exploration. Each gradual change feels monumental, like the spaced-out synth exploration on "Movement 7" or the Hammond organ passed through a vibrating Leslie speaker on "Movement 8." That Promises holds its own—and even stands out—within one of the most important catalogues in jazz is a remarkable achievement. —M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### DJ Manny - Signals In My Head (Planet Mu)
> 2021 was a golden year for footwork. This year, Planet Mu, once responsible for thrusting the Chicago genre onto the international stage in the mid-'10s, put out a trilogy of releases from stalwarts of this syncopated world: Jana Rush, RP Boo and DJ Manny. On Manny's contribution, the veteran Chicago-born, Brooklyn-based artist sought to bring romance to a genre historically known for soundtracking dance battles. If anyone could step up to this challenge, it would be DJ Manny and his smooth production style. Signals In My Head sees him whipping up some of the most airy atmospheres footwork has ever seen. Rosy melodies swirl into delirium while R&B vocals coo, sometimes lustfully and other times longingly, mellowing out its characteristically rougher rhythms and leaving only traces of a harder past.—Kiana Mickles Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Dean Blunt - Black Metal 2 (Rough Trade)
> Dean Blunt has long been an elusive character, quietly releasing oblique albums without liner notes and responding to interview questions in riddles. His entire body of work could be viewed like a museum of intriguing abstract paintings, open to interpretation but always astonishing. His most recent record riffs on its predecessor's Americana themes—heart-tugging strings, whining harmonica, desert rock guitar and somber and occasionally tongue-in-cheek lyrics that allude to loss, betrayal and the white critic's flimsy observations. But with the help of Joanne Robertson's girlish voice, as if brought down straight from heaven, Black Metal 2 emerges as one of Blunt's most approachable records. —K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Tirzah - Colourgrade (Domino)
> If Tirzah's breakout debut album Devotion was beloved for its intimate romantic love songs, the tracks on Colourgrade will be remembered for expanding the definition of what constitutes a love song in the first place. Moving out of the city and giving birth to two children, Tirzah examined other forms of love, like the camaraderie between creative partners or the bond between parent and child. Some tracks here make it difficult to parse whether she is referring to a lover, a relative or an old childhood friend, but the universality of it all makes Colourgrade a record that will age gracefully with repeated listens. Adding to its introspective beauty and warmth, the album is brought to life with grainy production and endearing imperfections (a cough here, incomprehensible whispers there). Charmingly unpolished and grounded in a human need we can all agree on—love—it's an album that encourages listeners to cherish life's smallest, most precious moments. —K.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### HTRK - Rhinestones (N & J Blueberries)
> People rarely talk about their favourite "band" anymore. HTRK, the Australian duo comprising Jonnine Standish and Nigel Yang, are one of a handful of groups that inspire this level of dedication in their fans. Their music holds similar qualities to other classic "favourite bands," like The Cure—their songs microcosms of ineffable longing and desolation. On their latest LP Rhinestones, HTRK continue to embrace stripped-down guitars, this time going for a twang and effects palette that evokes the Kodachrome skies of Wim Wenders' Paris, Texas. In the film, the sprawling vistas and stark photography set the stage for a hushed, heartbreaking drama. Here, the sparse guitar and unhurried progressions serve a similar purpose, foregrounding Standish's languid vocals. As usual, deceptively simple lines like"If you wanted to / Hang out with mе during the day," on "Sunlight Feels Like Bee Stings," hit like a brick. —M.M. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Joy Orbison - still slipping vol. 1 (XL Recordings)
> Long gone is the Joy Orbison who only makes club bangers. In his place sits a producer whose music is, with every new release, a truer, more vivid expression of not only his ever-broader tastes, but also his life and loves. Building on recent experiments with R&B and downtempo music, still slipping vol. 1 incorporates voice notes from his family—asking Joy how he's doing, making jokes, talking about weed brownies—into a cosy world of tunes that range from sedate garage to hooky, subdued pop. It feels like a Sunday afternoon in Joy's living room: vinyl all over the floor, loved ones popping in and out and talented friends occasionally jumping on the mic, all culminating into a more relaxed look at one of UK dance music's most quietly virtuosic producers.—Carlos Hawthorn Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music

### Mr. Mitch - Lazy (Gobstopper Records)
> It can take artists years—decades, even—to be able to authentically express themselves through their music. Mr. Mitch said this personal change occurred around the release of his 2017 album, Devout, a vulnerable record inspired by fatherhood. Not coincidentally, it was also the first time his fans had truly embraced his experimentations with slower tempos, ornate instrumentation and song-oriented structures. The Londoner built on this newfound freedom and confidence on this year's Lazy, with 11 tracks packing a range of energies and emotions. There are heart-rending tributes to his own musician father and strong statements about racism and social justice (the title is a reference to stereotypes about Black people), blending not only genres but personal and political messages in a way that could have felt forced and overblown in less accomplished hands. Instead, one feels profoundly moved. —C.H. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Loraine James - Reflection (Hyperdub)
> The late and great Mark Fisher feared that musical ingenuity was being replaced by desperate revivalism in the dying embers of late capitalism. If he was around now, Reflection might soothe those fears. James' mesmerising neo-IDM classic gestures towards dance music or bedroom R&B, only to take sudden detours into terra incognito that eludes categorisation altogether. (Nothing feels more appropriate than the outro being titled "We're Building Something New.") Sludgy, off-kilter kicks thud under pensive chords like some alien life form's interpretation of dance music. At times heartbreaking, at others startlingly vulnerable, James contemplates pandemic-era existentialism, projecting anxieties about the future with a ghostly delivery that feels like inner monologues being broadcast for all to hear: "This is a reflection / Just mine, not yours." —E.O Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music / Soundcloud

### Arushi Jain - Under The Lilac Sky (Leaving Records)
> Arushi Jain has a buzzy, larger-than-life personality, but you'd hardly know that from her restrained and gentle music. Constantly jumping from project to project, Jain always found solace in Indian classical compositions when feeling overwhelmed, and wanted her own work to channel the same healing qualities. On her second full-length, she captures the evening light in all its ever-changing glory, moving from sunset to darkness. Humming synths and drones conjure the flickering shadows of twilight, while her voice adds bursts of vivid colour. Aimed at instilling a certain kind of intentionality and meditation in its listeners, Under The Lilac Sky is a guaranteed palette cleanser for those seeking clarity or simply enjoying an evening wind-down.—Nyshka Chandran Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Conclave - Conclave (Love Injection)
> The self-titled debut from New York ensemble Conclave is a masterful study in rhythmic flexibility. True to their jazz roots, the group of rotating musicians—led by DJ and multi-instrumentalist Cesar Toribio—start the record as improvisational jams before narrowing down a vision and a concept. Their live approach is tangible: several tracks start on simple refrains before morphing into full-bodied flurries of dreamy funk, Afro-Latin percussion and downtempo beats. In homage to the clave (an instrument and rhythmic pattern), Toribio and his players concoct a joyous commemoration of the power of collaboration, unity and the cathartic energy of house music itself.—N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Spotify / Apple Music / Soundcloud

### Nala Sinephro - Space 1.8 (Warp Records)
> On her Warp Records debut, London-based harpist and modular synthesist Nala Sinephro creates introspective electronic soundscapes with warm exhortations from the UK jazz new guard (musicians like Nubya Garcia and Eddie Hick). Combining ambient music and spiritual jazz, Space 1.8 lands like a caress, owing to Sinephro's intuitive touch—she knows exactly when to press, linger or just hold still. "While my hands are doing their job, I’m almost sleepwalking," she told The Guardian in a recent interview. Ranging from meditative to pulsating—with an incredible, career-making 17-minute finale—Sinephro's ambitious but effortless compositions comfort and soothe in all the right places. —N.C. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

## [2020's Best Albums](https://ra.co/features/3787)
Date: 2020-12-23T12:00:59.000Z

### Various HOA 10-12 Haus Of ALTR 
> 2020's busiest electronic artist might have been Wyatt D. Stevens, AKA MoMa Ready. Beyond the dozen or so records he produced himself (including an LP with AceMo and two solo albums), there were the ten he released on his label, HAUS Of ALTR, three of which were towering achievements in themselves: HOA 10, 11 and 12, compilations of more than 25 tracks each, released in June, July and September, each of them presenting, in their own words, "the future of Black electronic music," the "Vangaurd in the war against white supremacy in electronic music," and a "march toward a future of unabashed Black electronic expression." These 72 tracks show dozens of vital artists from New York and beyond delivering their A-game or something close to it. Together, they form an embarrassment of riches we're still getting through half a year later. Listen: Bandcamp HOA010 / HOA011 / HOA12

### Slikback /// + ///II Self-Released 
> On September 1st, Slikback released ///, a surprise album that, at 30 tracks, doubled the size of the Nairobi artist's catalog in one fell swoop. Three days later, he released another 30-track bundle, ///||. He called them "a reflection of different vibes and emotions that make me... some rough, some gentle, some funny." The energy and artistry of these 60 tracks is stunning. Gqom, trap, noise, ambient, drill, footwork and techno all get tossed into Slikback's musical wood-chipper. Tempos run from around 70 BPM to over 170. Guest appearances range from Polish sound artist Morgiana Hz to the Ugandan MC Swordman Kitala. These albums should not be an easy listen—they clang, groan, shriek and bang, and sneak up on you when you least expect it. But instead of wearing you down, each new track lures you further in. You never know what kind of perfectly sideways groove is lurking around the corner. Listen: Bandcamp /// / Bandcamp /​/​/ II

### KMRU Peel + opaquer Editions Mego + Dagoretti Records 
> It's fitting that 2020 would produce a breakout star from the realms of ambient and field recording. Kenyan artist Joseph Kamaru, AKA KMRU, had been bubbling up already, but in 2020 he seemed to be everywhere, dropping tracks on his Bandcamp, appearing on the excellent Physically Sick 3, and releasing these two stunning LPs (along with a cassette, Jar) that show the incredible breadth of his sound. Appearing on esteemed avant-garde outlet Editions Mego, Peel is a silky abyss of droning soundscapes and spectral field recordings. Opaquer is its adventurous counterpart, with tracks like "Lost Ones" and "Canthenta" having more in common with bass-heavy experimental music than anything you'd typically call ambient. Together, they introduced many of us to an artist whose music is as powerful as it is subtle. Peel: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify opaquer: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Ulla Tumbling Towards A Wall Experiences Ltd 
> It doesn't lull you into a vegitative state, nor evoke a hotel spa lobby via rainforest field recordings. Instead, the side of ambient Ulla conjures on tumbling towards a wall carries you away with the subtlety of a daydream. The Kansas City artist has worn many aesthetic hats over the years, both on previous releases like Append and in projects like Pontiac Streator and the newly minted LOG. Her delicate compositional ear is clearer than ever on this release. Tracks like "stunned suddenly" and "new poem'' create space to think, without trying too hard to relax you. "feeling remembering," "leaves and wish" and "soak" are spotted with melodies and gentle textures—the album is ripe with soothing sounds, but never cluttered with them. You walk away from tumbling towards a wall feeling like the artist has told you something personal, a secret, and a precious one at that, even if you can't say exactly what it is. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### E.M.M.A. Indigo Dream Local Action 
> In the seven years since her debut album, E.M.M.A. has gotten comfortable composing soundtracks and scores—her recent work has found her soundtracking campaigns for luxury fashion houses like Gucci and Chanel. Her affinity towards large-scale, cinematic projects is reflected in the brief 35 minutes that make up Indigo Dream. Swirling '80s synths and club sounds collide on this mesmerizing album, sending us to the zenith of yearnful nostalgia and back again. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Theo Parrish Wuddaji Sound Signature 
> Even within Theo Parrish's catalogue, Wuddaji felt like a monumental entry. After innovating an often-imitated, never-replicated brand of deep house around the turn of the millennium, Wuddaji's eight tracks felt like a new milestone, or a jumping off point for some new, deliriously funky Black dance music. Dense, futuristic tunes like "Hennyweed Buckdance" are interspersed with floor-fillers like "Angry Purple Birds" and "This is For You." Wuddaji came with a map of Idlewild, a once-thriving vacation enclave in Northwestern Michigan that saw the likes of Aretha Franklin and Louis Armstrong performing for Black audiences escaping segregation in St. Louis and Detroit. Wuddaji, like so much of his music, draws from the personal and the historical, musical and otherwise. His deep understanding of the triumphs and injustices of the past—and their impact on the present—is raw material for groundbreaking art. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud / Sound Signature

### BOOF Rebirth Of Gerberdaisy Bubble Tease Communications 
> Maurice Fulton has a lighthearted, often humorous approach to dance music, and it's safe to say that BOOF is his quirkiest project. These records come out once every five years or so, are always named after flowers and feature elementary artwork that looks like it was made in Microsoft Paint (a stretched flower and clashing text). But beneath that exterior is some of the best work the American multi-instrumentalist has ever put out. Rebirth Of Gerberdaisy is no exception. In fact, it's the best BOOF record yet, with the gusto of a talented live band trying to work out as many dance genres as they can: minimal techno, piano house, stomping disco, jazz fusion and deep, soulful grooves. Of course it's not a band you're hearing, just Fulton going crazy on the organ, guitar and keyboards, a one-of-a-kind talent that makes every genre sound like something he invented. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Beatrice Dillon Workaround PAN 
> The idea of the lone genius is appealing, but most great records are the labor of many minds. On Workaround, South London-born artist Beatrice Dillon embraces the collectivity of music-making, weaving together acoustic instrumentation from 12 different collaborators with her software production techniques to create 14 rhythmically complex toe-tappers, all fixed at 150 BPM. Batu brings the hi-hats on "Workaround Six," which are nonchalantly assembled into a beat, while the malevolent thwack of stand-up bass comes courtesy of Swedish jazz musician Petter Eldh. "Workaround Two" has flushed synths and vocals from Laurel Halo. Dillon's catalogue is an advent calendar of distinct treats, containing dub techno abstractions such as 2015's Face A, experimental cassettes like Index Tape For Performance and Two Changes (with Rupert Clervaux). Workaround, galvanized by a crush on UK dance music, is cultivated through the diligent practice of purposeful limitation. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Various Physically Sick 3 Allergy Season 
> At the beginning of July, four months into the pandemic and six weeks into daily protests following the murder of George Floyd by police, Allergy Season and Discwoman dropped Physically Sick 3, a charity compilation that raised money for Equality For Flatbush, an organization fighting police brutality and gentrification that also helped residents of Brooklyn stay safe during COVID-19. Curated by Physical Therapy, Umfang and Frankie Decaiza Hutchinson, the music was exceptional—27 tracks of bold club sounds, plus the odd bit of noise and ambient, from a cast of artists that spanned continents and generations. The series' tradition of what it once called "electronic protest music" had never felt more necessary, and it was inspiring to see electronic artists rising to the occasion so readily. Beyond being some of the best music that came out this year, Physically Sick 3 was a how-to in DIY music activism. Listen: Bandcamp

### Ana Roxanne Because Of A Flower Kranky 
> Ana Roxanne's debut record, ~~~, had ambient fans in the palm of her hand, eagerly awaiting a follow-up. Her sound instantly had its own niche, drawing from New Age, devotional music and drone. Because Of A Flower is a more confident record than her first. It's conceptually provoking and brilliantly executed, full of vulnerability and understated beauty. Her enchanting vocals elevate Because Of A Flower above your typical ambient fare. It's a refined set of songs that seem to fly by and leave you in a different, more serene mood from where you started. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Jonnine Blue Hills Boomkat Editions 
> Many of the most cherished post-punk pop records—Young Marble Giants' Colossal Youth, Gareth Williams & Mary Currie's Flaming Tunes—are scrappy projects held together by spit and glue. Jonnine's Blue Hills fits that bill. Recorded at HTRK member Jonnine Standish's home in the Dandenong Ranges outside Melbourne, the nine-track album was a low-key affair, first released on cassette as part of Boomkat's series of quarantine records, Documenting Sound. But the spare songs, built on less-is-more bass lines and Standish's spectral vocals, punched above their weight with their effortless mix of the mundane and the sublime. "And hey, you're the best thing that I've had / because you want all the things that I have / And when the birds sing / they sing just for you / they live in blue hills," Standish sang, guiding the listener through the small psychodramas of a life lived in lockdown at the edge of the forest. Listen: Boomkat

### Moodymann Taken Away KDJ 
> Maybe you saw Moodymann in the flesh this year. Or caught his residency at Grand Theft Auto's new nightclub, The Music Locker. Most of us weren't so lucky. Instead, we sought consolation in Taken Away, a record so quintessentially Kenny Dixon Jr. it could probably form the basis of a biography. Detroit? Tick. Roller skating? Tick. Track after track of toasty gospel, house and hip-hop, peppered with sultry, sometimes madcap musings from the "most memorable voice in modern dance music"? Obviously. This LP had it all. Behold a masterclass in house music songwriting. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Yves Tumor Heaven To A Tortured Mind Warp Records 
> The highlight of Yves Tumor's show-stopping fourth album is "Kerosene," a collaboration with the singer Diana Gordon that isn't so much a duet as a collision, rising to a churning climax where Gordon's vocals feel like a cross between Dolores O'Riordan and Alanis Morrisette. It's a moment of fireworks on an album that functions like a powder keg, a 21st-century rock opera starring Tumor, flanked by an arsenal of session musicians and armed with oodles of vaporwave-style loops. Here, amid horn sections that rise up like tidal waves and guitar leads that go up against clipped funk samples, Yves Tumor emerges as something like the rock star they've tried to be for years: sexy, alien, suave, and a master of melodies that get stuck in your head. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Shinichi Atobe Yes DDS 
> No one knows much about techno producer Shinichi Atobe. The Saitama-based artist has been releasing albums on DDS for five years now, with the only communication between him and the label typically consisting of no more than a CD with track titles in the mail. Building on the warm housey elements that were the foundation's of 2018's Heat, Yes is chock full of bright melodies, and of course delivered with his trademark hi-fi production standard. There are also a few surprises, too, like the sci-fi synths on "Lake 3," the funk-driven pulse of "Ocean 1" and the Drexciyan touch of "Loop 1." Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Actress Karma & Desire Ninja Tune 
> There's always excitement around an Actress album, but for this year's Karma & Desire, Darren Cunningham and Ninja Tune went the extra mile. There was a prequel mixtape, which included a cryptic teaser tracklist for the album proper. There was a short film and a hotline you could call to hear a track down the phone. For a few days, rumours even spread of a second Actress mixtape, but it turned out to be the work of Dam Voyage. After all that, Karma & Desire had to be good. Cunningham delivered on the build-up and then some. What we got was a more open and fun version of Actress's early sound. The vocalists made the record more accessible. The instrumentals, too, were brighter and clearer. The album experience, its innovative preamble included, was a clear highlight of 2020. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Duval Timothy Help Carrying Colour 
> Duval Timothy's fourth album has a documentary writer's touch. With his piano front-and-center, the LP narrates a journey of healing and navigating the perils of the music industry, primarily drawing on minimalist jazz hooks and immersive sampling. Timothy has a gift for making gems out of the mundane. On Help, spare vocals are distorted and looped into oddball rhythms, while field recordings bring the compositions to life. It's one of those special, emotive albums that says a lot by doing less. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Yaeji What We Drew 우리가 그려왔던 XL Recordings 
> After creating dance floor bangers so universal they had festival crowds sing along with them, Yaeji took a backseat, preferring to collaborate and curate rather than release the long-awaited follow-up to her breakthrough EPs. What We Drew is a candid study of depression and ennui, how to break free from those things, and how to avoid beating yourself up when you do feel bad. The lead single is a tribute to the act of living: "I got hydrating down / I got listening down," she sings. On "Money Can't Buy," her guest Nappy Nina says, "Snuggly and sleepy / These naps come easy" after a verse of braggadoccio. What We Drew makes it clear that Yaeji connects with audiences around the world because she presents life as it is, celebrating the triumph of persevering and just getting the small things down, supported by love not only from others, but for yourself, too. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Jasmine Infiniti BXTCH SLÄP Self-released 
> More than most techno producers, Jasmine Infiniti embodies the euphoric potential of the genre alongside its darker impulses. Take "Downhill," where muddy drums thump beneath bright, neon-streaked synths. The American artist's debut album straddles this divide so well because of Jasmine Infiniti's lived experience as a person on the margins, where nightlife can be a trap as much as an escape. But for every moment of foreboding, there's a glimpse of light, underpinned by an elastic, almost buoyant sense of melody and rhythm, informed by her days in the Bay Area's vogue scene and the taut slap of ballroom music. It's a techno record unlike any other in 2020—heavy and light, ecstatic and paranoid. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Headie One Edna Relentless Records 
> The authorities coming down hard on Black music is nothing new, but the story around UK drill felt different. This time, even hugely influential platforms like YouTube shared in the vilification, removing videos at the request of the police. That was in 2018, which is incredible when you consider how far the genre has come since then. No one better embodies this turnaround than poster boy Headie One, whose excellent debut album, Edna, felt like a watershed moment for UK drill. Here was a #1 record laying bare the glory and despair of gang life in London, told through the eyes of not only its protagonist but a whole cast of rap stars, from local legends (M Huncho, Ivorian Doll) to global icons (Drake). Once again, Black street music, through a combination of grit and pure talent, had silenced its critics and conquered the mainstream. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

## [2020's Best Mixes](https://ra.co/features/3789)
Date: 2020-12-21T12:00:53.000Z

### Anz 
> Anz spring/summer dubs 2020 Anz's fifth production mix, spring/summer dubs 2020, was "built through turbulence and forged in feeling," yet somehow the tracks are fizzing with euphoria. Taken from an arsenal of a whopping 74 tracks made during quarantine, the UK producer compiled 84 minutes of summery UK dance music into this mix, which fans out over UK funky, 2-step garage, dubstep and jungle. The edit samples range from '90s hip-hop and R&B to the TikTok favorite "Renegade," which is remixed with raucous amen breaks. Conducta The Kiwi Sound Two years, two unbelievably good mixes from Conducta. The Kiwi Sound, the follow-up to 2019's #1 pick, hits many of the same notes: bouncy, bright and stacked with the best in fresh UK garage. It's a bold statement on the health of the modern scene, which has taken years to break through despite UK garage never really going away. Finally, everyone's favourite summer sound is back where it belongs: in the hands of young, talented tastemakers with the world at their feet. FAUZIA DISCWOMAN 87 "Almost didn't do this as I didn't think it was good enough," FAUZIA says of her DISCWOMAN mix, "but my friends forced me to see it through!" The idea of this all-originals mix not being good enough becomes almost impossible to conceive about halfway through, when she's blasted her way through Plaid-style IDM, throbbing deep house and stonking dubstep. The mix seems to catch the artist just as she's found her voice, like a bolt of lightning captured in a photograph. As tracks from it have trickled out on various releases through the year, FAUZIA's star has only grown brighter. This mix, frozen in time, is basically where it all started. Scott Zacharias & Patrick Russell IT.podcast.s09e05 & IT.podcast.s09e01 For a small but dedicated group within rave culture, it goes without saying that No Way Back, arguably the last vestige of the hallowed Midwest rave tradition, is the biggest event, of any kind, on the calendar all year. These two sets from this year's streamed edition show what's unique about the party, from the range of records played, to the peerless taste and panache of their selectors. Patrick Russell's set embodies No Way Back's bread and butter: leftfield techno and electro gems, drawn from decades of dedicated digging, perfectly arranged into a mind-bending slipstream of sound. Scott Zacharias, who usually plays the chillout room ("Outer Space") at sunrise, is the party's dessert, bringing a psychedelic soup of jazz, rock, dub, hip-hop, ambient, Italo, funk, soul and whatever else fits a sound he likes to call "sleaze." Together, these sets demonstrate the limitless possibilities not just of No Way Back, but of playing records in general. Job Jobse Sunrise at the last ever Nachtdigital All 140 minutes of this glorious mix encapsulate why we’ve been missing clubbing so much in 2020. It has everything: pop hits, rave classics, the hiss of the Nachtdigital crowd cavorting in the dawn sun. Early on, the heavens opened, followed by hours of unabated sunshine. Friends frollicked in the lake, partners kissed and embraced, and Job Jobse, the master of ceremonies, surveyed the sandy dance floor with the grin of a man whose dreams had come true. Listening to this mix brings it all flooding back. Juliana Huxtable Dekmantel 288 To take a line from one of her own poems, Juliana Huxtable’s Dekmantel Podcast contains a "PALPABLY HIGH LEVEL OF IDGAF ENERGY." The Texas-born artist is impatient behind the decks, knocking through visceral techno, vocal samples and industrial interventions with marvelous fluidity, compounding them into a hypnotizing sound collage that advances towards evermore stimulating sonic extremes. Change is a constant in this mix, and no genre is out of bounds. The permissive approach means it's packed with potential peak moments, poised and ready to encite euphoria for a range of listeners, whatever their niche. Nicolas Lutz at Phonoteque Nicolas Lutz has long been the maestro of playing records for which you'd happily trade a limb in return for an ID. Thanks to him and peers like Binh and DJ Masda, overlooked corners of house, techno, electro, trance and breakbeat history are now prime influences for a burgeoning audience of DJs and producers, many of whom might not have formerly paid mind to the so-called "minimal" scene from which those DJs emerged. This mix from Phonotheque—home base for Lutz, DJ Koolt and the rest of the Montevideo techno scene—shows things are coming full circle. More than ever, Lutz is playing new music that his sound has directly influenced. He's also reaching for records that fit into his taste bracket but come from sources you might not expect. It would've been unusual a few years ago that he'd play something by, say, Overmono. It speaks to how different parts of dance music are coming ever closer into orbit. Theo Parrish We Are All Gorgeous Monsterss Theo Parrish's We Are All Georgeous Monsterss is more than a DJ mix: it's a casually delivered manifesto. In the fever pitch of the largest protest movement in US history, Parrish uploaded, revised and eventually pulled down an expansive six-part set that drew direct connections between racial violence and the appropriation of electronic dance music from its Black roots. "You don't know what this music means to us, you only know what it means to you," Parrish intoned. "Now granted, you take your ideas, you run with it, you create your own shit, that's great, you create your own universe of it. Please, go right ahead, there's nothing wrong with being inspired, but my god, you can't have all of it!" Quotes and archival interviews break up Parrish's own spoken word as he unfurls hours of unreleased material, spanning from melancholy jazz piano to frenetic beat tracks. All the while, the Detroit artist detailed various indignities, from being pulled over to getting kicked off the decks at Berghain. If this is what Parrish, a massively respected innovator within the form, faces day-to-day, what does that say about the general experience of Black artists within the club scene? What went wrong? CCL Blowing Up The Workshop 111 DJing isn't always art, but Blowing Up The Workshop, Matthew Kent's dearly departed mix series, reminded us that it often can be. The series was historically important, hosting mixes from Galcher Lustwerk and Ben UFO that stood the test of time. But the series also helped migrate the concept of DJing away from the utilitarian and towards the deeply personal. CCL's contribution to 111—the seven mixes that sent BUTW out on a high note—fit the bill. Kent described the set, which spanned from dream pop to dubstep, as "a beautiful collage that feels like the reason I started the series in the first place." Akash pulled together a wistful 30-minute set of Bollywood tunes for 111, complementing Chris SSG's masterful three-hour ambient set and Dr Banana's moody garage and 2-step mix, to name just a few. BUTW felt like a natural home for all of these disparate styles, and this freedom often led to mixes worth cherishing. Kent's now moved on from BUTW, focusing on Mana Records, the label he runs with Andrea Zarza, but with any luck, BUTW's boundless approach will persevere.

### Theo Parrish 
> Theo Parrish We Are All Gorgeous Monsterss Theo Parrish's We Are All Georgeous Monsterss is more than a DJ mix: it's a casually delivered manifesto. In the fever pitch of the largest protest movement in US history, Parrish uploaded, revised and eventually pulled down an expansive six-part set that drew direct connections between racial violence and the appropriation of electronic dance music from its Black roots. ### <a href="https://beatsinspace.bandcamp.com/album/josey-in-space">Josey In Space by Josey Rebelle</a> 
> <a href="https://beatsinspace.bandcamp.com/album/josey-in-space">Josey In Space by Josey Rebelle</a> Josey Rebelle Josey In Space Beats in Space Records In the first few minutes of Josey In Space, we hear beautiful poetry about the Black experience from Tenesha The Wordsmith and Daniel B. Summerhill, in the shimmering track "I Dream So Loud." "I've seen dreams deferred / As many times as I've seen kids wish upon them…. Now / Not later but right now / More than ever I dream so loud." In the next track, we hear a one-off vocal sample: "Can't we rebel or something?" Those words stay in our head as we listen to the rich, unpredictable, deeply personal mix that follows. The beauty of DJing is you can play literally whatever you want, something that Josey Rebelle, a DJ since the age of 13, understands more deeply than most. Josey In Space, the second official mix in Tim Sweeney's Beats In Space series, has the same eclectic flex as her club and radio sets, drawing an arc from '90s hardcore to chilled UK hip-hop via house, techno, acid and jungle. But it's also highly focussed, bringing together these disparate sounds to give us something carefully considered: a paean to Black club music over the last few decades, from both sides of the Atlantic. "Yes, music is beautiful, it makes you happy," Rebelle told Chal Ravens this year in a cover story for DJ Mag. "But it's also a serious business, and you approach those decks with serious intentions to destroy the dance floor." Here, Rebelle's intentions are less dance floor destruction, more musical storytelling. But the dedication to craft is no less intense. Arriving one year after the BBC's #1 Essential Mix of 2019, Josey In Space once again shows Rebelle to be one of her generation's best.

## [2020's Best Tracks ](https://ra.co/features/3788)
Date: 2020-12-21T12:00:52.000Z

### Eris Drew Fluids Of Emotion Interdimensional Transmissions 
> When "Fluids Of Emotion" came out in February, Matt Unicomb's review asked, "Could this be the house record of the year?" Eris Drew's track makes a strong case for the title, all psychedelic breakbeat house with the same feeling of controlled chaos you get from her quick-fingered mixing of old rave records. The bounding drums, the uplifting harpsichord, the misty-eyed vocal sample: it's all put together with the love and intense emotion that defines Drew's signature sound. "It's the kind of track that unites a dance floor, so I hope I'm lucky enough to be on one when it gets played," Unicomb said. Most of us are still waiting for that opportunity. Luckily, the charm of "Fluids Of Emotion" feels timeproof, a rapturous feeling encased in wax. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Nazar Bunker feat. Shannen SP Hyperdub 
> Guerrilla, the illuminating debut album by Nazar, taught us something about the Angolan civil war. Rarely has electronic music tackled complex themes—politics, bloodshed, trans-generational trauma—in such a raw and compelling way. "Bunker," the second collaboration with London DJ and curator Shannen SP, was inspired by real-life events in Luanda in 1992, when Nazar's two older sisters barricaded themselves inside hotel rooms to avoid being found by government death squads. The anxiety is there in the helicopter whirrs and the cocking of guns. Both artists murmur lyrics in the detached drone of the shellshocked. Is that a knock at the door? The whole thing makes for harrowing listening. But still you go back for more. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Vytamin Outer Rim Terra Firma 
> It's like something from a nightmare: you release the biggest bomb of your life at a time when dance floors don't exist and socialising has been virtually outlawed. Not only that but your track is exceptionally festival-ready, all cosmic synths and fat breakbeats—the soundtrack, in other words, to a life-affirming dance floor moment. The good news is that "Outer Rim" isn't likely to be shelved any time soon. Tracks this special deserve a proper runout once parties return. Ravers must experience this beautiful banger in all its glory. Listen: Youtube

### DNGDNGDNG Hiperborea On The Corner Records 
> Peruvian duo Dengue Dengue Dengue planned a new alias for 2020's festival circuit. Abbreviated to DNGDNGDNG, the alias hasn't yet had a chance to live out its original intentions, but it was behind one of the year's standout EPs. Continentes Perdidos channels the mystical sound of, as the name translates, lost continents. On the highlight "Hiperborea," DNGDNGDNG excavate and innovate their Afro-Peruvian heritage. The record is rooted in the unpredictability of polyrhythmic structure; your ears try to follow one rhythm and before long, you're lost in a jungle full of them. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Andrew Ashong & Kaidi Tatham Washed In You Kitto Records 
> Andrew Ashong's last two releases—a collaboration with Theo Parrish and the go-to soul of his self-titled EP—date back to 2012 and 2014, so by October of this year we were long overdue another hit of his silky smooth voice. His 2020 mini-album, Sankofa Season, was well worth the wait, especially with the added bonus of broken-beat hero Kaidi Tatham on the buttons. "Washed In You," the effortlessly cool lead single, is everything you could wish for from the collaboration. Tatham's production pedigree shines through the skippy drums and roaming arrangement. His lush keyboard playing is the perfect accompaniment to Ashong's voice, as well as having its own moments to take centre stage. Sankofa Season marked the beginning of a new label project for the pair, Kitto Records. Hopefully there's more to come, and sooner rather than later. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### INT*era 548 Acting Press 
> INTe*ra is Vancouver's Hashman Deejay with PLO Man and C3Deee, two of the artists behind Acting Press. Aqueduct, their only release this year, shows what makes this label cult favorite, with six tracks that float between cosmic techno and a modern update of '90s West Coast ambient (see: Spacetime Continuum and his essential label, Reflective). "548" hovers gracefully between those sounds. Its atmosphere is part deep-sea, part deep-space, with a stepping techno pulse that enhances its weightless feel and a nine-minute runtime that makes it easy to get lost in. These guys do lush, transportive techno better than anyone, and this one showed them at the top of their game.

### Kush Jones Strictly 4 My CDJZ Vol. 8 Self-released 
> Kush Jones is committed to releasing 40 volumes of Strictly 4 My CDJZ. For anyone who follows the prolific producer's output, this goal seems well within reach. Opening the eighth volume of the EP series, "Bleep Bloop" is a clear standout from the series so far. There's punchy bass, soaring pads that drop and ascend like hovering airplanes, and as the cut's cheeky title references, an almost piercing melody that trickles throughout. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

### Anz Loos In Twos (NRG) Hessle Audio 
> Anz was one of 2020's success stories. First she turned heads with her mammoth spring/summer dubs 2020 mixtape, showcasing over 50 original tracks. Then she landed on Hessle Audio, an essential label for the kind of hybrid UK dance music she makes and plays. Her status as Manchester's new hero was cemented with "Loos In Twos (NRG)," where old-school rave synth stabs and breakbeats conspire for a lunging rhythm that sounds like it was designed to knock the needle off the record. Like so much of her music, it's a rush of energy and a ray of much-needed sunshine, a SAD lamp for a world without dance floors. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Terrence Dixon Galactic Halo Axis Records 
> The great thing about electronic music is that new trends appear periodically, giving us all a dose of something fresh. The other great thing is that some artists never change. Terrence Dixon belongs to the latter camp, a Detroit maverick who for 25 years has put out a steady stream of reliably excellent cosmic techno. This year's contribution to the canon was the Galactic Halo LP, which looked ahead to life on a strange planet in the year 2976. The standout track was "Quasar," a wonderfully simple roller built from a few bleeps and bloops ducking and diving across a firm pulse. Listen: Axis Records

### Pub Summer Ampoule Records 
> "Summer" is an anomaly on this list, as it was first released in 2000, during the golden era of dub techno. The Glaswegian artist Pub re-released it as a single this September, together with another glitchy ambient masterpiece on the flip. For many of us, this opened the floodgates to a vast and somewhat elusive discography, both his own and that of his prolific label, Ampoule. "Summer" sprawls out over 16 minutes, wandering leisurely and striking a perfect middle ground between ambient and dub techno. Its free-flowing, blissed out atmospheres will work perfectly for fans of Deepchord, Barker or Jan Jelinek. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Novelist Stay With Me Self-released 
> Novelist wore several hats in 2020—UK drill rapper, house producer, jungle MC—but the most surprising and compelling was the silky '80s sound of "Stay With Me." This love letter to Jesus, which came complete with a catchy chorus and belting sax solo, spotlighted the London artist's pop appeal and songwriting chops. There was a deeper message, too. Uploaded to Bandcamp the day before a major Black Lives Matter protest in London, "Stay With Me" was about remaining strong and hopeful in the face of adversity. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify

### Karenn Shoes Off Voam 
> If there was a prize for the year's weirdest banger, it would have to go to Karenn's "Shoes Off." Blawan and Pariah lightened up their joint project in the past couple of years, from the artwork and track titles on their label, Voam, to the extremes of this trancey number. The austerity of their last label, Works The Long Nights, is a distant memory. That's not to say the new music doesn't bang as hard, but the pair seem intent on drawing more fun and unusual sounds out of their arsenal of hardware. "Shoes Off" is Exhibit A. Somehow a playful melody, gritty kicks and rips of bass gel together. For a moment you would be forgiven for thinking you're listening to Four Tet or Bicep, until the snarling bassline boxes you square in the face. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Wata Igarashi Eruption WIP 
> The first two releases on WIP, the new label from Wata Igarashi, caught the Japanese techno maestro in a serene mood. By the third, he was back on the dance floor. "Eruption" is like listening to 2020 in microcosm. The mood begins pleasantly enough, before an industrial scrape, faint at first, swells to a deafening roar, the sound of planes crashing and buildings collapsing. A flash of white noise, then, quick as anything, the thunder slips away, leaving the kick drums and churning bassline, only this time there's something else too, all feathery and glorious. Light, perhaps, at the end of the tunnel. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

### Donato Dozzy The Tao Samurai Music 
> A Donato Dozzy drum & bass EP had been coming. His DJ sets have been incorporating more and more D&B, he has released a 170 BPM remix for Samurai Music already, and his label Spazio Disponibile has issued two 12-inches of half-time mind-melters from Mike Parker. "Tao," the title track from Dozzy's EP for Samurai, is a technical marvel and a fresh approach to 170 (or 85) BPM, borrowing heavily from his slow-release style of techno. The EP as a whole is another inspired, diagonal step in his discography. Listen: Bandcamp / Soundcloud

### Azu Tiwaline Magnetic Service Livity Sound 
> Azu Tiwaline's sultry take on "meditation music" draws you into a deep and expansive listening experience. Refractions of her more dance-focused project Loan periodically pass through Magnetic Service, producing dub and minimal techno apparitions. All her releases under this moniker look to music as the coupling between humans and the natural world. Inspired by local environmental soundscapes in the El Djerid region of southern Tunisia where she lives, the EP has an elemental richness, thanks in part to her use of field recordings and atmospheric synths. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### ELLES summers_of_love Naive 
> "End Of The Night" comes as the relaxed, four-to-the-floor closer of an EP focused on electro and 2-step, like the exhausted but blissful finale of a good night out. It's a sumptuous cut of dream-house with warm pianos, blissful sustain strings and ELLES' shyly deadpan vocal delivery. What really makes this track special is all the little moments—the touches of bird song, the cymbal crashes after the breakdown, the way the vocals start to stutter and phase—that send chills down your spine. These are the ingredients that bittersweet club anthems are made of. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Nico Six Rooms EP Akita Club 
> Before releasing music as Nico, Mexican artist Nicolas Guerrero appeared on labels like L.I.E.S., Styles Upon Styles and Blank Slate, under the guise of White Visitation or WV. Since 2018, he has departed from the barreling techno of that alias, veering towards a more colourful and open-hearted sound. His 2020 mini-album Six Rooms goes further, in Nico's own words, "away from the club and into empty houses and abandoned pools." He has a way with vocal chops and syncopated drums—which attracted the keen ears of Batu's Timedance and Midnight Shift—and he deployed both gracefully on the Six Rooms highlight "One Day." Listen: Bandcamp

### TYGAPAW Run 2 U Naafi 
> "Run 2 U" is one of so many tracks released this year that longs to be played in a club. Tygapaw's debut album, Get Free, manages to be both tender and barreling, exploring self-liberation with meditative spoken word and dopamine-laced, '90s-Detroit influenced techno. Roughshod and bursting with energy, "Run 2 U" sits somewhere near the middle of the album. It's so entrancing that you might want run it back before continuing the journey. Listen: Bandcamp / Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud

### Track of the year 
> Giggs Straight Murder (Giggs & David) feat. Dave No Bs Music Giggs and Dave, the two big stars of UK rap, couldn't be more different: Giggs is all presence and cheeky punchlines, while Dave is pure lyrical wizardry. Turns out, their styles complement each other. "Straight Murder (Giggs & David)," their second collaboration, showed both rappers at the top of their games, Dave relentless and razor-sharp, Giggs somehow both jovial and vicious. The wordplay is mind-blowing. And let's give a special shout-out to KeyzMusic, the man behind one of the best and most chilling beats of 2020. Listen: Apple Music / Spotify / Soundcloud 2020 India Jordan For You Local Action India Jordan wrote For You to document the process of coming to terms with their queer identity. Taking cues from happy hardcore, drum & bass and house, the record opens with blissful house tracks "I'm Waiting (Just 4 U)" and the title track, recalling the late-night euphoria of last year's DNT STP MY LV. The "you" here refers to Jordan, who has recently come out to the public as non-binary. There's a feeling of triumph that emanates from "For You." The track shows Jordan's knack for chopping and looping vocal samples, this one employing the amorous hook of Change's "You Are My Melody." The loop never gets old, and as satisfying as the final climactic breakdown of the track is, when the familiar hook comes back around, it makes you wonder why it left in the first place. But the vocals aren't all that make the track pop. "For You" is swaddled in an addictive sunny feeling, thanks to funky guitar riffs, seesawing '80s synths and rousing percussion. The track captures the dizzying joy of finding true love—in this case, the love of one's self.
